description: Well structured wine, with herbal and bell pepper flavors as well as delicious juicy black currant fruits. The fruit is enclosed in a firm set of tannins, offering some aging potential. The finish brings out the bright acidity of the vintage.
title: Château la Tonnelle 2008  Haut-Médoc

description: From Barton & Guestier's own chateau, the wine is a well-balanced spice- and berry fruit-flavored wine. Its tannins fit with the fresh 2008 acidity and lively, fruity character. Age for 2-3 years.
title: Château Magnol 2008  Haut-Médoc

description: A Cabernet Sauvignon-dominated wine, Lieujean is full, although showing some signs of austerity with tannins that are still very firm. It does have a fine, spicy, smoky character as well as black berry fruit and fine tannins. Age for 3-4 years.
title: Château Lieujean 2008  Haut-Médoc

description: The aromas here are seriously woody, and that problem also appears on the palate. It has fruit, but the weight to balance is not there yet. This should develop over the next 4-5 years, but the wood is always going to be a major feature.
title: Château Caronne Ste Gemme 2008  Haut-Médoc

description: A satisfyingly rich wine, with dusty tannins and a chunky, fruity structure. It has plenty of the typical black currant flavors of 2008, spiced with new wood. Ripe enough to drink now, but it will age.
title: Château Trois Moulins 2008  Haut-Médoc

description: Perfumed with new wood aromas and violets, this is a full-bodied wine, its tannins blending into sweet plum and cranberry juice flavors. The wood is finely judged, giving a rounded feel to the finish, along with the acidity.
title: Château Labat 2007  Haut-Médoc

description: Good density here, with tannins that spring from bright berry fruits. The acidity is certainly present, but it has weight behind it, giving potential richness balanced by wood.
title: Château Lieujean 2007  Haut-Médoc

description: This rich wine is juicy with black-currant fruit and crisp with acidity. The wood aging is just on the right side of too much, but shows in the wine's spicy, dry character. The fresh fruit should come through strongly as the wine matures. Drink from 2023.
title: Château d'Aurilhac 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: This is a structured, dense wine produced in the southern Haut-Médoc, close to Bordeaux. It is packed with dry tannins that give an austere character. The weight hints at the black-currant fruit to come. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Saint Ahon 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: Produced from organically grown grapes, still a rare concept in the Médoc, this wine from vineyards close to Margaux is stylish, fruity and elegant. Dry tannins form part of a juicy wine with blackberry fruits. Likely to age well over the next few years, it will be ready to drink from 2023.
title: Château Meyre 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: Ripe and fruity, this is becoming a delicious wine. The black-currant fruits from the Cabernet Sauvignon give both richness and crispness. With good acidity and a touch of wood, the wine will be ready to drink from 2019.
title: Château Laride 2014  Haut-Médoc

description: This estate lies in the far western reaches of the Médoc close to the forest, giving a cool character to the wine. It obviously been wood-aged, although with room left for the blackberry fruits. Spice and toast flavors are already integrating well, indicating the wine's potential. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Méric 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: A blend holding 55% Cabernet Sauvignon gives plenty of black currant fruit and provides the tannins that form the background to this richly juicy wine. Merlot adds weight to this perfumed, ripe wine that will be ready to drink from 2019.
title: Château le Chêne 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: This spicy, juicy wine has black-currant fruitiness from 60% Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend. It is rich, the wood aging still showing in the toasty edge. With its lively fruit and soft tannins, it will develop well over the medium term. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Laride 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: This light, fruity wine already has a good balance between bright fruits and the wood-aging. With black-currant flavors from the 60% Cabernet Sauvignon and spice from the 12 months wood aging, this wine is still structured and will be best from 2021.
title: Château Landat 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: This spicy, toasty has the potential for bright berry fruits. With acidity as well as a dry structure, it will need aging. This family estate dates back to the 19th century. Drink from 2023.
title: Château du Raux 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: In the village of Arcins, in the heart of the Haut-Médoc, this estate belongs to the Castel family, one of the largest drinks companies in France. This wine, with its generous tannins and ripe blackberry fruit, is easy, generous and likely to age well and quickly. Its tannic structure is fully integrated into the fruitiness. Drink this wine from 2023.
title: Château Barreyres 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: Associated with Château Rauzan-Gassies in Margaux, this is a surprisingly lean wine. Acidity comes from the red fruits and the wine is light. Red berries are just supported by tannins to suggest potential. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Bel-Orme Tronquoy de Lalande 2014  Haut-Médoc

description: A chateau owned by Benjamin de Rothschild. The wine has some richness, spiced with wood, blackberry, dark tannins and a potential for some aging. It also has the freshness from acidity that remains the hallmark of the 2004 vintage.
title: Domaines Barons de Rothschild (Lafite) 2004 Château Peyre-Lebade  (Haut-Médoc)

description: A perfumed, new wood-dominated wine, but one that does have the weight of fruit to support the wood. The tannins edge between fruit and wood, layered over rich black plums and bitter chocolate flavors. Under everything is fresh acidity to give the wine a welcome, vivid final lift.
title: Château Cambon la Pelouse 2006  Haut-Médoc

description: A lively, fresh, red-fruited wine, with a good balance between new wood flavors, spice and intense fruit. This is a great wine to drink now, with its direct fruit flavors backed with tight tannins.
title: Château Labat 2004  Haut-Médoc

description: This cool and crisply fruity wine is tight with acidity as well as red-berry fruits. The 25% Cabernet Franc in the blend gives an attractive perfume that fills out the wine and enhances the tannins that are still at its core. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Bonfort 2015 Châteu Bonfort  (Lalande de Pomerol)

description: This 65% Merlot wine is ripe, fruity and soft. Coming from a light vintage, it is ready to drink with its blackberry fruits and supporting tannins.
title: Château Vieux Cardinal Lafaurie 2013  Lalande de Pomerol

description: This small property in Lalande de Pomerol is owned by the Bertin family. In this vintage, they seem to have become excited by wood aging which shows strongly and dominates the Merlot fruits. With spice and bitter chocolate flavors, the wine will take time to soften. Drink from 2022.
title: Clos l'Hermitage 2014  Lalande de Pomerol

description: Full of jammy Merlot fruits, this is a smooth ripe wine. Dried fruits and tannins give the wine its varietal character. They are freshened by the acidity and black-currant fruitiness. The aftertaste allows the firm tannins to shine. Drink from 2017.
title: Maison Givas 2014 Vin No. 09  (Lalande de Pomerol)

description: The wine is firm and structured, showing more structure than fruit. It is solid, tight and with vanilla and blackberry fruits that are still behind the tannins. Probably this wine will remain firm, although the tannins should soften. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Moncets 2011  Lalande de Pomerol

description: This is the second wine from Siaurac, generous and ripely fruity. It is packed with juicy blackberries, acidity and an open, generous character. With its fruit and soft tannins it needs no aging. Drink now.
title: Château Siaurac 2013 Baronne de Siaurac  (Lalande de Pomerol)

description: This is a soft ripe wine. It has generous helpings of Merlot that give red fruit and rich acidity. The wine is soft for the vintage and is all ready to drink.
title: Château de Chambrun 2011  Lalande de Pomerol

description: Now managed organically, this estate has produced a light, fruity wine. Fresh red berries are sustained by a firm tannin edge that offers a solid base for the fruitiness and acidity. Drink from 2017.
title: Château des Annereaux 2011  Lalande de Pomerol

description: This is fully mature with its leather and toast flavors enhanced by a smooth, rich texture. It is a delicious wine to drink now, with some red fruits and final acidity.
title: Château des Annereaux 2006  Lalande de Pomerol

description: Smooth and perfumed, this is already drinkable after decanting. With wood aging, dusty tannins and solid black fruits, it is both rich and forward. The tannins and the acidity both promise aging, so while it is ready to drink now, it will be better from 2016.
title: Château des Moines 2012  Lalande de Pomerol

description: Lalande de Pomerol is the northern extension of Pomerol, so it's no surprise to find this wine dominated by Merlot. It is soft, rounded and rich. Black plums give the fruitiness while black fruit skins provide the texture. It's a full wine that needs a little aging. Drink from 2016.
title: Château Vieille Dynastie 2012  Lalande de Pomerol

description: Considering the average reputation of the 2007 vintage, this is a very drinkable wine. It is maturing, with a developed color and mushroom flavors. The acidity and the soft structure both show a wine that's ready to drink.
title: Château des Annereaux 2007  Lalande de Pomerol

description: While the wine certainly has structure, its main character, from the dominant Merlot, is the juicy, stalky fruit and jammy, ripe black plums. It does have an edge of bitter chocolate and a layer of wood. When that softens, it will be a ripe, broad wine. Drink from 2017.
title: Château de Roquebrune 2011 Cuvée Reine  (Lalande de Pomerol)

description: This rich, full-bodied wine is becoming smooth and ripe. The tannins are enveloped by the generous black fruits and drier raisins. A core of dryness show the wine is still developing. Drink from 2015.
title: Château Laborde 2009 Cuvée 1628  (Lalande de Pomerol)

description: This Merlot-dominated blend has resulted in a wine that is both juicy and structured. With its forward flavor of black currant juice, it is surprisingly ready to drink, although the tannins also promise aging. It's ripe and dense, while the final acidity offers a fresh finish
title: Château La Croix Romane 2010  Lalande de Pomerol

description: This is structured and firm, with its dry tannins prominent along with blackberry and black cherry acidity. The wine does have density, a dusty texture and the chance to further age.
title: Château Haut-Goujon 2008 La Rose Saint-Vincent  (Lalande de Pomerol)

description: Ripe black fruits combine with bitter chocolate and toast from the wood to give a very ripe wine. It is structured at this stage but is likely to ripen and round out over the next 3-4 years to give a rich, smooth, Merlot style.
title: Château Sergant 2009  Lalande de Pomerol

description: A solid, chunky wine, with a structure that is full of corners and edges. The tannins are in a dusty, chewy style, balancing with the fresh black fig and sweet plum juice flavors. Rich and concentrated, the wine needs to age.
title: Château Tour Grand Colombier 2005  Lalande de Pomerol

description: This soft, fruity wine is ripe with the generous black fruits of the vintage. The tannins are well integrated into the structure and open texture. Drink this wine from 2019.
title: Château Bourseau 2014  Lalande de Pomerol

description: One of the properties owned by Jean-Louis Trocard, former president of the Bordeaux Wine Council. La Croix des Moines is a 29-acre property which, in 2004, produced a finely structured wine, packed with dark tannins, supported by a good weight of blackberry fruits. Wood is not an issue in this wine; the fruit and the fruit tannins tell the story.
title: Château la Croix des Moines 2004  Lalande de Pomerol

description: One of the stars in Listrac, Fonréaud is producing a modern style of wine, with plenty of new wood. The flavors are ripe, black, generous, while allowing a sense of elegance as well.
title: Château Fonréaud 2000  Listrac

description: A wine initially dominated by wood, but opens to show ripe, black fruits, flavors of herbs and firm, dry tannins. From an 88-acre vineyard in the west of Listrac, this is a finely structured wine, which will certainly age well. Imported by Heidelberg Distribution.
title: Château Fonréaud 2003  Listrac-Médoc

description: Partly owned by New York resident Peter M. F. Sichel, this is a property that has considerably improved. This 2003 has richness, some good new wood flavors and and an open character. The fruit is packed with ripe, black flavors and there is softness to the aftertaste that is immediately appealing. Imported by Parliament Wine Co.
title: Château Fourcas Hosten 2003  Listrac-Médoc

description: From one of the leading estates in Listrac, this is a ripe structured wine. It has firm tannins and a dark core of dry wood aging. Balanced with that is the blackberry fruit and generous superripe Merlot. The wine needs time, so don't drink before 2019.
title: Château Saransot-Dupré 2014  Listrac-Médoc

description: This wine is well balanced between its juicy black-currant fruits and dry tannins. The high percentage of Petit Verdot (20%) gives both the color and the firmer tannic background. It is beginning to age well, so drink from 2017.
title: Château Reverdi 2013  Listrac-Médoc

description: Initially rough around the edges, this wine opens up to give warm red berry fruits, firm tannins and a solid structure. Underlying tannins give a dry core. A more juicy, fresh aftertaste means this wine needs some aging. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Saransot-Dupré 2011  Listrac-Médoc

description: A lean wine, hard-edged and with austere tannins. It has some berry fruits that are submerged by the tense tannins and acidity. At the end, smoky wood aging flavors dominate.
title: Château Vieux Moulin 2011  Listrac-Médoc

description: An unusually high proportion of Petit Verdot (30%) gives this wine both its color and its firm, dark structure. It's a rich wine, the tannins underlying ripe black plum skin flavors and a spicy aftertaste. Give this wine until 2016.
title: Château Reverdi 2011  Listrac-Médoc

description: A year's wood aging has left its mark on this wine in the form of burnt smokiness. However, the fruit is rich and full-bodied giving the promise that the wine will smooth out its rough edges. There already is a fine juiciness at the end that comes with great acidity.
title: Château Cap Léon Veyrin 2011  Listrac-Médoc

description: With its rich, ripe blackberry-jam flavor and soft tannins, this is an immediately accessible, fruity wine. The tannins provide structure that accompanies the ripeness, although this is not a wine to age for many years.
title: Château L'Ermitage 2009  Listrac-Médoc

description: This is a very rich wine with black fruit and bitter coffee flavors and dense tannins. Its weight is almost too much for the firm structure that is underneath.
title: Château Cap Léon Veyrin 2009  Listrac-Médoc

description: Owned by the same family since 1850, this estate has produced a ripe Merlot-dominated wine. It is densely structured and full of black-currant fruits. The crisp fruitiness of the year shows strongly. Drink from 2018.
title: Château de Tabuteau 2014  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: Owned by the Riviére family, which also owns a large negociant business, this estate has produced a solid darkly tannic wine. Dominated by Merlot, it is rich, juicy and full of blackberry fruits. The fresh acidity of the vintage is still very present. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Haut-Piquat 2012  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: Full of the ripe fruit and structure of the vintage, this Merlot-dominated wine has big, bold tannins, spice and a dark, firm structure. The jammy fruits are developing well, likely to result in a generous, full-bodied wine from 2017.
title: Château Tour de Ségur 2012  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: From Château des Landes' old vines, this is a concentrated, solid wine. Dark tannins have dark chocolate and licorice flavors, with a structure that dominates the fruit and needs to soften. New wood aging was perhaps excessive, but give the wine time. Drink from 2017.
title: Château des Landes 2011 Cuvée Prestige  (Lussac Saint-Émilion)

description: All the richness of Merlot is apparent in this dense and concentrated wine. It has dark tannins, ripe blackberry fruitiness and a firm, dry structure. The tannins and acidity promise aging. Drink from 2016.
title: Château de la Greniére 2010  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: Full in the mouth, this is a ripe wine, showing wood, dark plums and a firm layer of tannins. There is a good black-fruit feel, brought out by the wine's acidity. This is serious and worth aging. Drink from 2017.
title: Château la Jorine 2011  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: Rich red fruits along with a stalky element give this wine weight and structure. It's on the dry side, with the fruit tannins and wood notes still dominant. Good acidity offers a bright aftertaste.
title: Château la Jorine 2010  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: Even though it is weighty, very full and dense, the wine has a fine balance, with acidity that cuts through the richness.
title: Horeau-Beylot 2009 Château la Fleur  (Lussac Saint-Émilion)

description: A fresh, fruity wine, with cigar and wood aromas, spice and light black fruits. This wine comes from before the renaissance that is taking place at Lascombes, and shows the lightness of the wines produced under the old ownership. It is balanced and fresh, with a good, dry aftertaste.
title: Château Lascombes 2001  Margaux

description: A dense wine that is showing signs of heavy extraction, with dark chocolate and bitter flavors. In a vintage with crisp fruitiness being the defining factor, it is a bit of a shame. The dark edge needs to mellow before the wine can balance out.
title: Château Marquis de Terme 2014  Margaux

description: Strong wood aging and toasty flavors dominate this wine. They give a hard extracted edge which takes away from the black-currant fruitiness. While this will soften, the fruit in this vintage should have been allowed more expression. Drink the wine from 2020.
title: Château Mongravey 2014  Margaux

description: Fruity and perfumed, this is already an attractive wine. Dusty tannins are working with the black-currant fruitiness to produce a fresh, lightly structured wine. Like many wines of the vintage, it will develop quickly, so drink from 2018.
title: Château Paveil de Luze 2013  Margaux

description: This fresh, ripe wine has plenty of juicy black-currant flavor. It is crisp, strengthened by tannins and with a great burst of acidity. It needs to calm down and round out before it will be ready to drink. Wait until 2018.
title: Château la Tour de Mons 2013  Margaux

description: This wine is solid and dense with probably too much extracted tannins. There are only hints of fruitiness. It will soften although it's likely to remain stalky. This is the first vintage in which some of the vineyard was managed organically.
title: Château Marquis de Terme 2013  Margaux

description: This wine has attractive black-currant fruits and fresh, light acidity. It's an early-developing wine with soft tannins and a stalky backdrop. Drink from 2018.
title: Chateau d'Angludet 2013  Margaux

description: This wine is toasty and spicy with black-currant fruits that are still developing. It is fresh although its firm structure needs time to soften. As it matures, it will develop a balance between fruit and tannins. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Haut Breton Larigaudiére 2013  Margaux

description: From the northern edge of Margaux appellation, Grand Tayac is dominated by Cabernet Sauvignon. It has elegance, light wood flavors and generous black currant fruits. The tannins just give support, bringing out the style of the wine. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Grand Tayac 2011  Margaux

description: A softly textured wine, this has richness coming from black and red berry fruits. Wood and juiciness combine well in this attractive wine that will be ready to drink in a few months.
title: Barton & Guestier 2010 Thomas Barton Réserve  (Margaux)

description: A wine with potential. The elements are all there: red berry fruits, a firm line of ripe tannins and the acidity to go with them. It needs at least four years before they come together into a structured whole.
title: Château Castelbruck 2009  Margaux

description: A fresh wine, with some of the richness of the vintage showing in up-front red berry fruits. The tannins are already well integrated, allowing the wine to show a softer side. It is for medium-term aging.
title: Château Grand Tayac 2009  Margaux

description: This wine from an 11-acre property is soft and ripe, with plenty of ripe berry fruits. Hints of the 18 months in wood are still there although they are not at all obtrusive. It is an easy wine just touched by spice, and will be ready to drink by 2018.
title: Château Carreyre 2015  Margaux

description: Linked by ownership to another Margaux estate, Tour de Mons, this wine reflects the ripe fruit of the vintage. Its tannins are still firm although they are well balanced by the bright black-currant fruit. This generous wine will be ready to drink from 2019.
title: Château Marsac Séguineau 2015  Margaux

description: This intriguing wine is dominated by the 60% of normally rare Petit Verdot. Made by the same team as Château Paloumey, this wine shows an impressive color, and a rich, black berry juicy character. The tannins are solid, but the exuberant fruit overrides everything else.
title: Château la Bessane 2006  Margaux

description: Dense, rich and still young , this wine has excellent potential. Firmly structured and full of blackberry fruits, it comes from the small village of By in the northern Médoc. It likely will ready from 2021.
title: Château Cailloux de By 2016  Médoc

description: This bottling forms part of a range of five wines produced by the Lafite-Rothschild winemaking team. Made from grapes grown in the northern Médoc, it is ripe and full of black fruits and rich tannins. Drink this wine from late 2019.
title: Domaines Barons de Rothschild (Lafite) 2016 Légende  (Médoc)

description: Still surprisingly dominated by its wood aging, this is a rich, spicy wine. Black-currant fruits and juicy acidity need more time to develop and balance out the wood. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Castera 2012  Médoc

description: A fine effort from this reliable cru bourgeois, the 2002 Rollan de By boasts hints of toast and vanilla in its bouquet, but mostly offers up solid cassis fruit, with just a whiff of dried herbs. A velvety, supple texture and lush tannins suggest early drinkability. Try now-2010.
title: Château Rollan de By 2002  Médoc

description: The wine is rich and packed with ripe black fruits. The firm tannins are comfortably cushioned by the ripe texture. This is young, although developing well. Drink this wine, with its fine potential, from 2019.
title: Château la Valiére 2014  Médoc

description: A ripe, soft and rich wine that will be ready to drink soon. It has black plum and berry fruits, ripe soft tannins and light acidity. The wine has a crisper cooler aftertaste. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Leboscq 2014  Médoc

description: Both the tannins and the wood aging flavors are strongly evident in this wine at this stage. But with the intense black-currant fruit and the acidity, it is going to be a ripe while also structured wine. The estate dates to the 14th century. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Castera 2014  Médoc

description: Jean Guyon owns a group of estates in the northern Médoc village of Bégadan. This wine (blended by a former "best sommelier in the world") has a high proportion of Merlot. That produces a wine that is smooth and likely to develop easily and quickly. With its touch of tannin, it is balanced and fruity. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Tour Seran 2014  Médoc

description: Ripe Merlot and layers of toasty wood flavors are the initial tastes of this young wine. It does have weight and plenty of blackberry fruit. The aftertaste is crisp and fruity with a dry edge from the young tannins. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Pierre de Montignac 2014  Médoc

description: The wine comes from a large estate of more than 100 acres. A balanced blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot has given an equally balanced wine. Black-currant fruit, some firm tannins in the background and a juicy aftertaste all give this wine an attractive character that will benefit from some aging. Drink from 2020.
title: Château de Panigon 2014  Médoc

description: Crisp and fresh, this is a bright wine. It has some attractive tannins as well as fine acidity. With a light structure and black-currant fruit, it should be ready to drink soon, certainly from 2021.
title: Château Potensac 2014 La Chapelle de Potensac  (Médoc)

description: The high proportion in the blend gives it its ripe, juicy character. The toasty wood aging flavors are just enough to allow it to fill out as it ages. With juicy black-currant and ripe-berry flavors, the wine will be perfumed and delicious from 2018.
title: Château Haut Barrail 2014  Médoc

description: This is an attractive, crisp and fruity wine. It has layers of wood that are already integrating well with the black-currant fruitiness. Tannins and a firm core are signs that the wine will age well. Drink this attractive wine from 2018.
title: Bernard Magrez 2014 Château Tour Blanche  (Médoc)

description: This is a perfumed, juicy wine. It has attractive red-berry fruits and touches of black currant. Still young, the wine is still shot through with tannins and a firm structure. This will soften over the next year to give a fruity, smooth wine. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Poitevin 2014  Médoc

description: There are strong elements of the wood aging in this structured wine. That gives it a dry character that still dominates the red fruits. It needs to develop. While it will always have a dry character, look for the fruit to shine with its berry flavors and acidity. Wait to drink until 2018.
title: Cheval Quancard 2014 Monfort Bellevue  (Médoc)

description: With a blend of 53% Merlot and the remainder from two Cabernets (Sauvignon and Franc) the wine is full of red fruits that are strengthened by firm tannins. Blackberry and black-cherry fruits are lifted by acidity while rounded out by the wood-aged spice. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Labadie 2012  Médoc

description: This smooth, ripe wine offers attractive black-currant fruits. It is spicy, with balanced layers of wood along with acidity and a juicy aftertaste. The structure is there, although the fruit dominates. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Carcanieux 2013  Médoc

description: This ripe wine shows plenty of blackberry fruits balanced well with some dry tannins. It is fresh, juicy with plenty of acidity, For a light vintage, it's perfumed, full of fresh flavors and will be ready to drink from 2017.
title: Château les Ormes Sorbet 2013  Médoc

description: The dominance of Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend of this structured wine gives strong tannins and tight black currant fruit at this young stage. It has good potential, however, a solid and powerful wine that needs several years. Drink from 2018.
title: Château la Tour de By 2012  Médoc

description: Ripe and juicy, this is an attractive wine already. It is packed with black currant flavors from the 60% Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend. That gives the wine a fruity character, allowing the drier tannins a supporting role that promises some aging. Drink now and to 2022.
title: Château la Valiére 2012  Médoc

description: Packed with ripe Merlot, this rich wine has spice and plenty of new wood flavors that partner with ripe berry and plum. It's juicy, fruity and structured for aging. It's developing into a full, opulent wine for medium-term drinking.
title: Château Tour Seran 2012  Médoc

description: A blend of half-and-half Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon, this is a solid wine. The tannins are still quite dominant although they are ripe and will integrate well into the red and black berry fruits. Acidity at the end keeps the wine fresh and fruity. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Tour Haut-Caussan 2012  Médoc

description: With vineyards close to the Gironde, this is a well-situated Château. This 2012 is one of the best from the property for several years, giving ripe tannins, balanced wood and good black currant acidity. It's not for long-term aging, so drink from 2017.
title: Château Loudenne 2012  Médoc

description: Ripe and attractively fruity, this wood-aged wine has ripe tannins that are still firm and strong. The fruit is still young, full of black currant flavors and bright acidity. These elements give a wine that has structure and needs to age. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Laffitte Laujac 2011  Médoc

description: Ripe and luscious, this is full of red berry fruits and black plums. Soft tannins pulse through the rich texture, giving shape while not taking away from the open character of the wine. It will age relatively quickly, so drink from 2016.
title: Château Griviére 2012  Médoc

description: Fresh-fruited and well balanced, this has firm tannins that are already well integrated into the black currant flavors and acidity. Solid and structured, it will develop well. The aftertaste brings out the acidity.
title: Bernard Magrez 2012 Château Tour Blanche  (Médoc)

description: For the vintage, this is a ripe, bold wine. Layers of delicious black fruits are supported by firm tannins and the right amount of wood aging. Balanced and dense, it will age well. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Pierre de Montignac 2012  Médoc

description: A ripe, juicy and fruity wine, this is already softening. Plenty of rounded Merlot flavors are stiffened by the wood-aging spices and the stalky black currant character of Cabernet. Drink this structured wine from 2018.
title: Château Moulin de Canhaut 2012  Médoc

description: While this is a firm wine, full of dry tannins and smoky wood-aging flavors, it also has plenty of ripe and juicy fruit. Red berry and black currant show strongly, filling the wine out and promising roundness as it ages. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Greysac 2012  Médoc

description: Strong wood aromas and flavors show that this is a young wine. It has a powerful, smoky structure, with a grainy texture that is still covering the fruit. The potential is there, though, the black currant fruitiness beginning to develop. Give it time and drink from 2017.
title: Château La Pirouette 2011  Médoc

description: This ripe, wood-aged wine has full berry fruits and ripe tannins. The spicy wood is still prominent but is allowing the rich fruit flavors to come through. It's structured and still firm, a wine that's mineral in texture and firm at the end. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Clos du Moulin 2011  Médoc

description: The wine is mature, with smoky acidity, autumn leaf aromas and a sense that is beginning to dry out. With its memories of berry fruits and the arrival of a leather texture, it should be drunk now.
title: Château Témperance 2006  Médoc

description: This super-rich wine is dominated by ripe Merlot that is given structure by leaner Cabernet Sauvignon. The wine is ripe, full of black plum flavors and dark tannins. Touches of licorice and wood aging flavors give a bitter edge to this powerful wine. Drink from 2015.
title: Château Haut Canteloup 2009  Médoc

description: Smooth and rich, this is already a delicious wine. It has soft tannins, a touch of wood aging and swathes of ripe black plum fruits. Gently structured, with some smokiness, it's going to age relatively quickly, so drink from 2016.
title: Château Rollan de By 2011  Médoc

description: A perfumed wine, it's full of soft, ripe black fruits. Spice and gentle tannins support the rich fruitiness. A touch of wood gives bitterness at this stage, and that needs to soften. The aftertaste though has the freshness of the vintage.
title: Château Lestruelle 2011  Médoc

description: While the tannins in this wine are firm and dry, it also has attractive black fruitiness, sweet berry flavors and a refreshing acidity. That gives the wine balance and a lift. It is developing well but needs time, so drink from 2017.
title: Château Clément Saint-Jean 2011  Médoc

description: An obviously wood aged wine, with burnt toast and spice dominant at this young stage. Happily, there is enough black currant fruit and fruity acidity underneath to support this overdose of wood. Give it time to fully integrate, and drink from 2016.
title: Château Bois Cardon 2011  Médoc

description: Rich and fruity, this wine shows black currant fruit along with a firm, dry and tannic core. This youthful balance is finished with a polish of new wood and fine acidity.
title: Château Lacombe Noaillac 2011  Médoc

description: A solid, ripe, juicy black fruited wine, delicious already with its fragrant fruits. It has structure that supports the attractive surface, giving shape to this lightly textured wine. Keep for 4-5 years, but also drink now.
title: Château de la Croix 2009  Médoc

description: A classically structured wine, this has a smoky wood flavor that's balanced by a fresh black-currant note. It has a juicy edge, a dark chocolate note and a slight bitterness that should fade. This needs to age for 4-5 years. Château Loudenne is situated by the Gironde estuary.
title: Château Loudenne 2010  Médoc

description: Dense and dark in color, this wine has a black currant flavor. The tannins are ripe and soft, and the texture has a fresh lilt to it from the acidity and fruitiness. Only on the finish do the youthful tannins show, promising medium-term aging.
title: Château Bessan Ségur 2010  Médoc

description: Tough tannins set the scene for this firm and extracted wine, giving it a smokiness and a touch of bitter fruit. However, the wine has the weight to support the tannins, and it hints at future juicy fruit. Keep this for at least five years.
title: Château de Panigon 2010  Médoc

description: While this shows its youthful tannins, it also bears blackberry fruit and juicy acidity. The chateau has produced a stylish wine that's rich while still keeping plenty of freshness and acidity. Age for 3-4 years.
title: Château Maison Blanche 2010  Médoc

description: This is a well-balanced, smoky and aromatic wine that has a good balance between dry tannins and black currant fruits. With its acidity and touch of minerality, it should age over the next 2-3 years.
title: Duval & Blanchet 2009 Les Notes ParFumées  (Médoc)

description: Ripe and juicy, this is packed with black currant fruit and lined with soft, open tannins. The wine has a dry core, yet this is surrounded by attractive smoky fruit and bright acidity. Ready to drink now.
title: Château Beauvillage 2009  Médoc

description: Dark-colored wine with a firm structure from ripe fruit. It is solid, dense and showing considerable richness. An explosion of ripe fruit goes with the tannins. Worth aging for 3-4 years.
title: Château Leboscq 2010  Médoc

description: With flavors of wood aging as well as sweet tannins, this is a concentrated and richly fruity wine. It has the ripe fruit of 2009, sweet berries, the tannins cushioned within the softness.
title: Château Bellegrave 2009  Médoc

description: Balanced and lightly structured, this wine offers a soft blend of Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon. Its open fruit, accessible tannins and red-berry flavors make for a wine that will develop quickly. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Haut-Bana 2015  Médoc

description: This fruity wine is soft, rounded and already shows a good balance between fruit and tannins. It has a lightly dry core but the red-berry flavors and acidity are up front and give this wine its immediate attraction. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Les Trois Manoirs 2015  Médoc

description: This northern Médoc estate has produced a wine that has both structure and fruit. The tannins are certainly present, giving a burnt character from the wood aging. However, black currant flavors are there as well. Put the two together as they integrate, and the wine will be juicy and attractive. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Noaillac 2015  Médoc

description: This is one of the most northerly of the Médoc estates, only six miles from the ocean. That gives a cool feel to the wine, emphasizing fruit rather than structure. Plenty of juicy acidity gives the wine a lift. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Lacombe Noaillac 2015  Médoc

description: This is the first vintage of this estate under the ownership of the Bouey family, which has a Bordeaux negociant business. The wine is dry, anchored in tannins at this stage although the juicy black fruits will come through over time. Wait for this wine until 2022.
title: Château la Ribaud 2015  Médoc

description: This 60-acre estate has produced a spicy, wood-laden wine. Rich fruit saves the wine from being overwhelmed by the toastiness and gives it the necessary weight. It will need time, so drink this wine from 2023.
title: Château Pierre de Montignac 2015  Médoc

description: This well-balanced wine offers a great mix of tannins and juicy fruit, It is rich and likely to be delicious as it matures, conveying weight as well as blackberry flavors and acidity in abundance. The wine needs to age over the medium term. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Lassus 2015  Médoc

description: From a property owned by the Bouey family since 1998, this wine is generous, ripe and offers attractive black-currant fruitiness. A blend led by 70% Merlot, it is soft and rounded, with a core of tannins for a bit of aging. Drink from 2021.
title: Maison Bouey 2015 Château Lestruelle  (Médoc)

description: This structured wine comes from an estate that has records going back to the 13th century. A blend of half-and-half Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon, it is firm and tannic at this young stage. The juicy black currant fruit is beginning to develop, bringing with it plenty of crisp acidity. Drink this wine from 2023.
title: Château Ramafort 2015  Médoc

description: Owned by the Cruse family, one of Bordeaux's major negociants, this estate was their original purchase in Bordeaux. With more than 60% of Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend, this wine is packed with black currants and tannins in equal measure. As the wine softens, it will broaden out to emphasize its richness and the warm fruit. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Laujac 2015  Médoc

description: The 39-acre estate is under the same ownership as Château les Trois Manoirs. This wine has a generous use of wood that has nicely stopped short of smothering the fruit. While the wine offers plenty of spice and toast, it also offers juicy black currants and acidity. The two elements are coming together and the wine will be ready from 2023.
title: Château Chantemerle 2015  Médoc

description: Vineyards in the Press family's 450-acre estate surround one of the Médoc's grand chateaus owned by Bordeaux elite over centuries. The wine from 155 planted acres has been spiced with 12 months in wood, giving a toasty character to the juicy black-currant fruit. It is a structured wine, ripe and with good potential. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Castera 2015  Médoc

description: The Beuvin family runs this Médoc estate, which grows Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot. The wine is full of ripe berry fruit and still-firm tannins. It has a good, juicy future, so drink from 2019.
title: Les Hauts de Tousquiron 2014 Cuvée Lucie  (Médoc)

description: A wine that certainly brings out much of the rich, dense character of 2005. The tannins are solid and dry, but with all that black berry fruit and ripe acidity, this is a fine achievement. It holds up well on the finish, bringing out sweetness as well as freshness.
title: Barton & Guestier 2005 Thomas Barton Réserve Privée  (Médoc)

description: With 50% Cabernet Sauvignon, this shows its origins in the gravel soils of the northern Médoc. The fruit is ripe, very pure and fresh, dominated by black currant acidity, with an edge of cranberry tannin. There's a dry core here, which gives the wine a firm structure.
title: Christian Moueix 2005  Médoc

description: The wine is seriously structured for the vintage: that means a wine that is full of tannins, dark and firm. It has concentration and black fruits, shot through with acidity. Drink this dense wine from 2018.
title: Maison Givas 2014 Vin No 1  (Montagne-Saint-Émilion)

description: The wine has ripe Merlot with red-berry fruit flavors and balanced tannins. It's fresh with the acidity of the year. Here it is contrasted with spice, a smooth surface texture and a ripe cherry aftertaste. This is an attractive wine to drink from 2017.
title: Château Tour Bayard 2013  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: This five-acre property has produced a ripe wine that is more about fruit than structure. Although there are tannins, the bold, black fruits and fresh acidity show best. The aftertaste is fruit with a generous texture. Drink from 2018.
title: Château les Hautes Graves 2012  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: This ripe, concentrated wine brings out the fruit of the vintage, ripe blackberries and currants. Tannins integrate well into the fruity character of the wine. Black cherry acidity comes through strongly at the end.
title: Château Faizeau 2012 Sélection Vieilles Vignes  (Montagne-Saint-Émilion)

description: This wine is perfumed both from the Cabernet Franc in the blend and the new wood used for aging. It gives a rich character with black fruits, firm tannins and a dense texture. The 22 different parcels of this estate face Saint-Émilion across the valley.
title: Château Haut Bonneau 2012 Cuvée des Ducs  (Montagne-Saint-Émilion)

description: Big, ripe and fruity, this dense and juicy wine is full of blackberry fruits, with a good tannin and acid balance. A dark structure will allow the wine to age, so drink from 2016.
title: Château la Fleur 2012  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: A complex, ageworthy wine, this is powered by its tannins, its dark berry fruits and the layers of wood aging. It's rich and sweet, the fruit balancing the structure and given a fresh touch with black currant acidity. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Plaisance 2011  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: This ripe, smooth and generous wine also has a good sense of elegance. Acidity, ripe berry and plum fruits and a core of tannins all hang together well to give a wine that's both dense and sophisticated. Drink from 2016.
title: Château Bonfort 2012  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: Ripe and fruity, this is already a delicious wine. It has blackberry fruit, sweet tannins and acidity that percolates through the ripe texture. Generous and open, it is almost ready to drink.
title: Château Rocher Calon 2011  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: This richly perfumed wine is firm with tannins, showing its high alcohol through a sharp peppery edge. It is dense and concentrated, almost too much so to pair with food.
title: Château La Bastienne 2009  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: This shows the rich density of Merlot in 2009, giving a solid structure, with dried fruit and red berry flavors and a concentrated line of tannins. Big and dense, this is ready to age.
title: Château La Fleur Plaisance 2009  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: A richly textured wine, showing some attractive fresh fruits and soft berries mingling with a layer of firmer tannins. The wine has weight, an attractive edge of spice and a final sweet juicy character.
title: Château Plaisance 2006  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: This 30-acre property is planted to 85% Merlot, with a blend of the two Cabernets for the other 15%. In this vintage, the wine is smoky while also full of rich fruit. Some firm tannins and the acidity add to the blackberry fruit to promise aging. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Piron 2015  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: This so-called satellite appellation of Saint-íˆmilion is able to produce attractive, forward wines, like this one. The ripe, soft structure brings out the black fruits, rounded out by sweet juiciness. There is a slight edge of astringency, but then the smoky wood and berry flavors kick back in.
title: Château Calon 2005  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: Yes, it has 2003 ripeness, but there is also some restraint here. The tannins are still defiantly young, the fruit packed with black plum jelly flavors. It promises 2-3 years' aging.
title: Château la Grande Barthe 2003  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: This is the first vintage under the Barton (of Léoville-Barton) family ownership. It is a structured wine with some dense tannins and acidity. The fruit is behind the tannins and will probably leave a firm wine. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Mauvesin Barton 2011  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: This 19-acre property, in the same family since the 17th century, has produced a structured, Merlot-dominated wine that is as much about tannins as fruit. It's still young and all that juicy black currant fruitiness will blossom. Give it until 2017.
title: Château Guitignan 2012  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: This perfumed wine is full of both tannins and juicy black fruits. The wood aging shows lightly on the palate but will integrate well with another year or two. Full and rich, it will be ready to drink by 2017.
title: Château Myon de l'Enclos 2011  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: Solid and structured while fruity, this is a rich, Merlot-dominated wine. It has bold black currant fruit flavors and tannins that are already well integrated. It will develop over the medium term, so drink this juicy wine from 2017.
title: Château Duplessis 2011  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: A firm wine that has solid, dry tannins as well as rich fruit. It shows minerality, structure and a firm character that suggests potential for aging. The wine also has rich fruit that balances the density well, its acidity cutting through. Drink from 2016.
title: Château Myon de l'Enclos 2010  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: A suave wine, concerned at this stage with its tannins and not with fruit. It is dry, the black plum skin texture just giving an opening to black currant fruits. All this means that this is a wine for aging-give it five years.
title: Château Haut-Bellevue 2008  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: This wine comes from a six-acre estate that belongs to the owners of neighboring classed growth Château Croizet-Bages. Get through the initial dirty barnyard character and there are density, generous tannins and black fruits. Hints of wood aging and juicy acidity are present along with a firm aftertaste. Drink this wine from 2022.
title: Château Richebon 2014  Pauillac

description: One of the best vintages for many years from this rather forgotten property. The wine is developing fast, already well integrated, powerful and dense, but dominated by attractive, ripe fruit. Imported by Diageo Chateau & Estates.
title: Château Grand-Puy Ducasse 2003  Pauillac

description: An attractively proportioned wine, not big and powerful, but gentle and immediately attractive. There is plenty of black fruit there, along with soft tannins and fine acidity.
title: Château Grand-Puy Ducasse 2000  Pauillac

description: This wine is soft and fruity with ripe berry fruits and gentle tannins. For a major second wine, it's surprisingly easy and soft, developing fast with its berry fruits, chocolate and wood flavors at the end. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Mouton Rothschild 2012 Le Petit Mouton  (Pauillac)

description: The second wine of Château Pibran, this is ripe, juicy and attractive now. Black and red fruits burst from the glass, giving a rich character. That is balanced with refreshing acidity and a light tannic character. The wine will develop quickly, so drink from 2017.
title: Château Pibran 2010 Château Tour Pibran  (Pauillac)

description: A finely made wine, with elegant fruit and tannins, but definitely on the light side. The red berry fruits are soft and juicy, already a pleasure to drink, with only short-term aging.
title: Château Lynch-Moussas 2007  Pauillac

description: Soft, juicy and fruity, relatively light in character. The tannins are fresh, supporting black currant and fresh, juicy fruit flavors. It's easy and open, developing well, but quickly.
title: Château d'Armailhac 2007  Pauillac

description: Fresh, fruity, relatively lightweight, this offers immediately pleasurable drinking. Tannins give a counterpoint, but only play a minor role. For drinking over the next 2-3 years.
title: Château d'Armailhac 2006  Pauillac

description: This wine shows all the fruitiness that is characteristic of this attractive vintage. It also brings in ripe berry fruits along with a background of firm tannins. Drink this structured wine with its appealing fruit from 2019.
title: Château Bardins 2014  Pessac-Léognan

description: With a high proportion (60%) of Merlot, this is a ripe wine while also being structured. It has a dense character that comes from the still young, firm tannins. Behind these are the ripest black-currant fruits, crisp and juicy, packed with flavor as well as acidity. Drink this wine from 2019.
title: Château Bardins 2011  Pessac-Léognan

description: This is a big and juicy wine full of blackberry and dark-plum flavors. The second wine of Larrivet Haut-Brion, it is fruity with dominant Merlot and round and perfumed Cabernet. It is developing rapidly into an accessible, ripe wine. Drink from late 2016.
title: Château Larrivet Haut-Brion 2012 Les Hauts de Larrivet Haut-Brion  (Pessac-Léognan)

description: This wine is dry but rich enough with black-currant flavors to compensate. The juicy aftertaste suggests the wine will develop quickly. Drink from 2017. This wine is the latest result of renovations on the 15-generation and 400-year-old Trocard family estate.
title: Château Mancédre 2013  Pessac-Léognan

description: Dry and structured, this dense wine has some austerity that comes from the dry tannins and extracted, bitter flavors. The aftertaste shows more of the tannins and dryness. Drink from 2020.
title: Château la Louviére 2012  Pessac-Léognan

description: While the tannins are very present in this wine, it also has good acidity and blackberry fruits. It's firm and structured in the front, still young, although allowing plenty of room for the fruit to show strongly over the next few years. Drink from 2019.
title: Château le Sartre 2012  Pessac-Léognan

description: A small property owned by Château Carbonnieux, Haut-Vigneau has produced a serious while still fruity wine. Its spicy wood is attractive and gives a warm character to the cherry and red berry flavors. The wine will certainly age over the medium term, so drink from 2016.
title: Château Haut-Vigneau 2012  Pessac-Léognan

description: Big, fat and juicy, this wine has soft tannins and a full-bodied structure. It is full of the superripe Merlot that characterizes 2009, making the wine develop relatively quickly. It should be ready to drink by 2016.
title: Château Baret 2009  Pessac-Léognan

description: Made by the same team as Château de France in Pessac-Léognan, this is an attractive, forward wine. It shows the juicy character of the vintage, although the tannins do give it structure and some weight. A wine for medium-term aging: 4-5 years.
title: Château Coquillas 2011  Pessac-Léognan

description: Hugely rich, the wine has a density that detracts from the natural elegance of this appellation. Its tannins and extracted fruit are firm although with the potential of juicy black-currant acidity as the wine progresses. Give this wine several years and don't drink before 2022.
title: Château Baret 2015  Pessac-Léognan

description: An attractive, balanced, drinkable wine that is soft in texture, almost ready to drink now. The pure black currant fruits are fresh and bright, with light wood flavors.
title: Château Bouscaut 2006  Pessac-Léognan

description: A serious wine, which still offers rich, powerful fruits. The aromas are of herbs and red fruits, the tannins are dense, with berry flavors, and the final effect is of great pure fruit.
title: Château Lafleur-Gazin 2000  Pomerol

description: This is a firm, toasty and tannic wine that reflects its tough vintage. Made from 100% Merlot it has ripe fruit that was aged for two years in wood to give that spicy woody character. The fruit still needs time to enhance the rich texture of the wine. Drink from 2020.
title: Domaine Roses Camille 2011  Pomerol

description: Dense with almost 100% Merlot, this is a rich wine. It has tannins that are cushioned by the ripe fruit and lifted by the acidity. The wine is dense with fruit, likely to develop quickly. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Nenin 2014 Fugue de Nenin  (Pomerol)

description: There is a good structure here, plenty to support the fresh fruits and red-berry flavors. This wine is full of fresh acidity with fruit and tannins in balance. It's going to develop well, always full of fruit and attractive acidity. Drink from 2018.
title: Château du Domaine de l'Eglise 2013  Pomerol

description: This stylish Merlot-based wine has juicy red-berry flavors that are sustained by acidity and firmed up by tannins. Still dry from its dense structure, it's developing well. Drink from 2018.
title: Clos Beauregard 2013  Pomerol

description: This wine is full of juicy fruit along with a dark, smoky character. A firm undertow of very dry tannins brings out a firm structure. The hard edge needs to soften, so wait to drink until 2018.
title: Château la Patache 2011  Pomerol

description: The second wine of Château Nenin wears its high alcohol easily. It is balanced, showing its dark tannins and juicy Merlot fruitiness in equal measure. It's by no means ready to drink, so age at least until 2018.
title: Château Nenin 2012 Fugues de Nenin  (Pomerol)

description: A big, rich blockbuster Merlot, this has dark raisins and black plum flavors that dominate the background tannins. Its power comes from the superripe fruit and the concentration of the structure. Age for 3-4 years.
title: Le Carillon de Rouget 2009  Pomerol

description: There is lovely richness here, with fresh acidity and red berry fruit flavors. The texture is round, lightly chewy, with some wood and final stalky fruit.
title: Château la Bassonnerie 2007  Pomerol

description: Relatively lightweight, the wine has soft, stalky tannins and flavors of hedgerow fruits to go with the well-judged layer of smoky wood. It is dry, firm and fresh.
title: Château Vray Croix de Gay 2007  Pomerol

description: Bright, round wine, with a layer of firm mineral tannins, but more about black berry and plum fruits, jammy acidity and a finishing dry structure. This second wine of Vray Croix de Gay will be ready in 2-3 years.
designation: L'Enchanteur de Vray Croix de Gay
title: Château Vray Croix de Gay 2007 L'Enchanteur de Vray Croix de Gay  (Pomerol)

description: Rich, yet firmly structured, this wine comes from Christian Moeuix's home territory. It's no surprise then that it is a great expression of the appellation, a full expression of ripe Merlot, truffles, fruitcake, generous tannins and a tobacco-scented finish.
title: Christian Moueix 2005  Pomerol

description: Plenty of dense texture here, derived from a liberal use of wood. That gives spice to the black berry fruit and bitter chocolate extract. In two years, this will be showing well.
title: Mähler-Besse 2008 Blavia  (Premieres Cotes de Blaye)

description: A spicy wine, all new wood with plenty of toast. The fruit, however, is rich enough to cope, giving a mouthfilling wine, dense and sweetly tannic with a firm, ripe finish. Age this wine for another year.
title: Château Haut Bertinerie 2005  Premieres Cotes de Blaye

description: Using the ripeness of 2003 and adding to it by high extraction, the wine has moved from Bordeaux to New World. The fruit, which certainly has some attractive blackberry jelly flavors, has been overoaked, giving power and intensity.
title: Confiance 2003  Premieres Cotes de Blaye

description: A dense, solid wine, still showing young fruit flavors, but with the toast from the wood aging there is a touch of burnt wood and spice. There's great acidity, fresh black currant flavors and some smokiness.
title: Château la Bretonniére 2005 Elevé en Fûts de Chêne  (Premieres Cotes de Blaye)

description: A selection of the best Cuvées creates a wine that has some weight and density, although the extreme juiciness gives fresh black currant flavors. The tannins are present, but soft.
title: Mähler-Besse 2007 Blavia  (Premieres Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: From a 250-acre vineyard on the slopes of the Entre-deux-Mers above the Garonne river, this wine is silky smooth, attractively balanced with wood and soft but dry tannins. Flavors of dark chocolate, black plums and spice from the wood all blend together well. To finish, there is good acidity.
title: Château les Hauts de Palette 2005  Premieres Cotes de Bordeaux

description: This wood-aged wine from Lamothe de Haux is rich and concentrated. The toasty flavors from oak give a fascinating edge of complexity to the smooth vanilla and black plums of the fruit. It could age over 2 years.
title: Château Lamothe de Haux 2004 Premiére Cuvée  (Premieres Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: This well-structured wine has spice, ripe blackberry fruits and a rich texture. The tannins are still firm, giving a strong, dry core to the wine. But everything is in place for good, medium-term aging. From 2021, the wine will be rich, packed with fruit and ready to drink.
title: Château Lanbersac 2015  Puisseguin Saint-Émilion

description: Almost pure Merlot (95%), this wine is richly endowed with generous fruitiness as well as firm tannins. It's a young wine-all fruit and structure at the moment-and it needs to fill out. When it does, it is going to be a ripe generous wine. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Lanbersac 2014  Puisseguin Saint-Émilion

description: Produced from organically grown grapes, this wood-aged wine from the Dupuy family is rich and full, packed with black plum and ripe berry flavors. With 30% Cabernet Franc in the blend, the wine is perfumed and structured with a smoky aftertaste that is balanced by acidity. Drink this well-made wine from 2017. The vineyard was certified organic in 1996, early in Bordeaux terms, and is managed by Gérard Dupuy.
title: Château Beauséjour 2012  Puisseguin Saint-Émilion

description: This dense wine comes from a 50-acre estate, large by the region's norm. It's concentrated, showing signs of extraction although not enough to hide the black fruits and fruit tannins. Dominated by ripe Merlot, it will develop relatively fast. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Lanbersac 2012  Puisseguin Saint-Émilion

description: On the slopes above the eastern Bordeaux town of Sainte-Foy, this vineyard produces some fine wines. Aged in new wood, the wine is rich in tannins, complex and serious. Bright red fruits and a firm structure both promise aging. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Bellevue Peycharneau 2013  Sainte-Foy Bordeaux

description: This wine hovers between being lightweight and dense. It's certainly mature, with tar and rose aromas, followed by spice and cigar box notes, and layered with acidity. Drink now.
title: Château Martet 2007 Réserve de Famille  (Sainte-Foy Bordeaux)

description: Initial big, tough tannins are then cut through with fresh fruits, plums and black berries. There is some spice here, and maybe the tannins remain hard-edged, but in 2-3 years this will soften out to give a big, bold, rounded wine.
designation: Cuvée Diane Elevé en Fûts de Chêne
title: Château le Pré de la Lande 2004 Cuvée Diane Elevé en Fûts de Chêne  (Sainte-Foy Bordeaux)
winery: Château le Pré de la Lande

description: Perfumed with mint and wood flavors, this rich wine has tannins that show strongly against the red-fruit flavors. This suggests a wine that needs to age, so wait until 2020.
title: Château Pré La Lande 2016 Diane  (Sainte-Foy Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: This wine is packed with blackberry flavors layered with the acidity of the vintage. It's floral, crisp and moving comfortably to maturity. Drink from 2019.
title: Château de Lescours 2014  Saint-Émilion

description: Rich and generous, this wine from the winemaking team of Lafite-Rothschild is dominated by Merlot from vines on the plain of Saint-Émilion. It has great swathes of blackberry fruits, ripe tannins and just the right amount of acidity and wood aging to keep everything in shape. Drink from 2019.
title: Domaines Barons de Rothschild (Lafite) 2016 Légende  (Saint-Émilion)

description: This wine is perfumed, structured and rich. Full of black-currant flavors, rich in tannins and obviously still very young, it is going to develop into a powerful, ripe wine, with plenty of fruit and mature tannins. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Haut-Cadet 2016  Saint-Émilion

description: This blend of 80% Merlot and 20% Cabernet Franc is ripe, showing red-berry flavors and an excellent potential. Made from organically grown grapes, it is perfumed and richly fruity, with spice and juicy acidity at the end. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Moulin de Lagnet 2015  Saint-Émilion

description: A slight step down from the nonmevushal bottling, with less plumpness on the midpalate and slightly roasted, but similar, flavors of chocolate, mocha, cedar and bacon. Supple on the finish, this is a blend of 70% Merlot, 30% Cabernet Franc. Imported by Royal Wine Corporation.
title: Château Valandraud 2002 Kosher Mevushal  (Saint-Émilion)

description: This is Gérard Perse's home, and he has done wonders for a vineyard on the sandy plain of Saint-Emilion. With 2000, the property has shone, producing a serious, complex wine that boasts black fruits and solid tannins. The acidity and wood flavors give it shape and leave a delicious, lingering taste.
title: Château Monbousquet 2000  Saint-Émilion

description: Displays handsome aromas and flavors with a complex mix of plummy fruit, earth, mushrooms, violets and lavender, and dusty cocoa. Attractive balance with good body and texture. Blackberry and coffee flavors mark the finish, which sports full but well-dispersed tannins. Appealing now, but has some aging potential, too. Accessible, affordable, appellation-bearing Bordeaux. Best Buy.
title: Barton & Guestier 1998 Roi Chevalier  (Saint-Émilion)

description: This producer, based in the eastern edge of Saint-Emilion, has these vines in the flat plain that leads to the Dordogne river. The wine has richness that comes from the vintage while also having structure and power. The juicy acidity and blackberry fruits are still developing, so drink from 2019.
title: Château Robin des Moines 2010  Saint-Émilion

description: Produced at one of the group of chateaus owned by the Ducourt family, this wine is bright, fruity and with a light tannic touch. It has a fine balance between its black fruits and its structure which will let it age well. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Jacques Noir 2014  Saint-Émilion

description: Ripe berry fruits give this wine its richness. There is a strong acidity as well that cuts through the wine leaving a stalky tight young fruitiness. Let the wine soften and drink from 2020.
title: Château La Serre 2014  Saint-Émilion

description: The third wine of Château Valandraud, this is a lighter version of the estate. With its generous tannins and concentration, it is smoky, full of blackberry fruits and the potential to age for a few years. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Valandraud 2014 3 de Valandraud  (Saint-Émilion)

description: Strongly dominated by its wood aging, this is a toasty, licorice and dark-coffee-flavored wine. It does have some black-fruit weight that should allow the wine to balance out. So wait until at least 2019 before drinking.
title: Château Pindefleurs 2014  Saint-Émilion

description: This is a fruity wine with contrasting wood-aging spice and high toastiness. It is still young with the acidity still prominent, so the two elements should blend well over the next few years to give a ripe, fruity wine. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Haut-Pezat 2014 Prélude du Château Haut-Pezat  (Saint-Émilion)

description: As its color indicates, the wine is approaching maturity. It has a rich texture with red fruits, some firm tannins and a generous character. With its spice, ripeness and concentration, it is fine to drink now, although the wine does fade quickly after opening.
title: Château de Lescours 2010  Saint-Émilion

description: Produced from 60-acres of vines on the plateau east of Saint-Émilion village, this is a fresh and fruity wine. It has layers of tannin surmounted with red cherry and black-currant fruits. The wine, with its dominance of Merlot, is developing well and will be ready to drink from 2018.
title: Château Boutisse 2013  Saint-Émilion

description: This wine is full of black-currant freshness. It is already delicious, crisp while just lit up by tannins. It is developing quickly, with a refreshing character that will make it drinkable from 2017.
title: Château Teyssier 2013  Saint-Émilion

description: This rich, smoky wine has an appealing streak of ripe black-plum flavors. What it is missing in all this richness is enough acidity, although the tannins will certainly allow it to age. Drink this powerful, ripe Merlot from 2017.
title: Château La Croix Chantecaille 2012  Saint-Émilion

description: Although this is still young, it's already possible to taste the outlines of a dry, lightly fruity wine that has considerable tannins. Some juicy black-currant acidity is showing freshly against the lean structure. The wine will age quickly, and should be drunk from 2017.
title: Château Cormeil-Figeac 2013  Saint-Émilion

description: After four years, this wine is showing ripe, smooth Merlot fruitiness with red berries and attractive acidity. It is light in texture although well balanced with acidity, a tannin underlay and silky aftertaste. Drink now.
title: Château de la Cour 2011  Saint-Émilion

description: From one of three estates owned by the Moreaud family in one contiguous 61-acre property, this smooth and ripe wine is all about rich black fruits. Supported by just the right amount of tannin and acidity, it is already delicious and fruity. Drink now, but better to wait until the end of 2016.
title: Château Magnan-Figeac 2012  Saint-Émilion

description: Set on the plateau of Saint-Émilion, this 12-acre property has produced a structured and firm wine. It is solid with tannins, dark with its black fruits and rich with superripe Merlot. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Truquet 2012  Saint-Émilion

description: This property was recent purchase by Château Ausone, but the 2012 was made by the previous owners. It has some rusticity and an earthy character that gives dryness as much as fruit. It should open out, but the wine will always be dry. Watch this estate for the future as the new winemaking team makes its mark.
title: Château la Clotte 2012  Saint-Émilion

description: A parcel within the Château Simard vineyard gives this wine that features plenty of fruitiness, with attractive acidity and black currant flavors. It also has structure, a touch of minerality and final, dry tannins, all of which will allow it to age. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Haut-Simard 2012  Saint-Émilion

description: Big and beefy, this has layers of dark tannins lying over the big black plum fruit flavors. With a solid texture that comes from this rich, dense vintage, the wine is still developing. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Trimoulet 2010  Saint-Émilion

description: This shows both the fruit of the vintage and a more structured tannic side. Black currant flavors are up front, offering a generous feeling. They are balanced by the backdrop of tannins and tight acidity. Together they make a wine that is concentrated and likely to be ready to drink soon. Drink from 2016.
title: Château Teyssier 2012  Saint-Émilion

description: Produced from vines on the plain of Saint-Émilion near the Dordogne river, this is a Merlot-dominated wine. It has big tannins, bold ripe fruit and a dark core of dryness. As with so many wines in this vintage, the fruitiness makes it work so well, ripe and bold black fruits that are finished off with acidity. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Haut-Pezat 2012  Saint-Émilion

description: Initially a tough proposition, this young wine then opens up to bring out ripe blackberry fruits, some solid tannins and a juicy character. It is still firm and dense and needs several years to age, so drink from 2017.
title: Clos Cantenac 2012 Petit Cantenac  (Saint-Émilion)

description: A blend of wine from different Saint-Émilion vineyards, this is a solid, balanced effort. Rich berry fruits are sustained by the underlying dry, tannic structure. It is powered by sweet ripe fruits that are well finished by the fresh element of acidity. Drink from 2015.
title: Fortin Plaisance 2011  Saint-Émilion

description: This is a big and ripe wine, with flavors of chocolate and blackberry. Dense tannins dominate, although the rich berry fruits and acidity promise a more fruity future. It's worth waiting; drink from 2018.
title: Château Franc Pipeau 2011  Saint-Émilion

description: A strong showing of Cabernet Franc in the blend gives this wine a rich and perfumed character with some firmer tannins. From the Merlot the wine has ripe berry fruits, black currants and tense acidity. It has freshness as well as a more solid character. Drink from 2017.
title: Clos Junet 2011  Saint-Émilion

description: A concentrated, ripe wine, full of toasty new wood flavors as well as dark berry tannins and acidity. It is dense, full in the mouth and packed with ripe fruit. Drink from 2016.
title: Château le Prieuré 2011 Délice du Prieuré  (Saint-Émilion)

description: The second wine of Château Chauvin is a structured, perfumed wine with its high proportion of Cabernet Franc giving much of its potential richness and spice. The tannins are solid and will always show well as an integral part of this complex wine.
title: Château Chauvin 2011 Vieux Château Chauvin  (Saint-Émilion)

description: The wine feels very dense, juicy, dark and concentrated. It has a huge feel to it, a powerful wine that will need several years to fully soften and round it. And, At 15.5% alcohol, this is way too heavy for a Bordeaux.
title: Château Cantin 2010  Saint-Émilion

description: The tannins are firm and dry, producing a solid structure. A black currant flavor emerges slowly, offering a fruity counterpoint. Although the wine-named after the cedar trees on the property-is ripe and tarry, it needs another year or two.
title: Château La Fortine 2008 Cuvée Les Cédres  (Saint-Émilion)

description: Big and densely tannic, this wine's fruit is still firmly buried in the structure. It has wood, spice and ripe plum notes. With its concentrated texture, it is still capable of aging.
title: Château Tourans 2006 Cuvée Terre Blanche  (Saint-Émilion)

description: Some wood aging gives this Merlot-dominated wine a full structure, with attractive tannins and juicy black fruits. It is ripe, full-bodied and very approachable now.
title: Barton & Guestier 2010 Thomas Barton Réserve  (Saint-Émilion)

description: 87-89. Barrel sample. Smooth and rich, this wine is dominated by firm tannins, tarry fruit and new wood.
title: Château Bellefont-Belcier 2011 Barrel Sample  (Saint-Émilion)

description: Ripe fruits, very smooth and polished, are primarily of a juicy black currant character over sweet ripe tannins. Great swathes of fruit finish this solid wine.
title: Château Teyssier 2008  Saint-Émilion

description: Soft and full in the mouth, with spice adding an extra dimension to the broad berry fruits. The wine is ready to drink, its acidity melding well into the richness. The final taste is solid and dense.
title: Château la Croix Melin 2008  Saint-Émilion

description: Firmly structured, this is a significant improvement on 2007, with the wood kept in play but not dominant. That's because the fruit is so bright, with juicy berries bubbling along, leaving refreshing acidity at the end.
title: Mähler-Besse 2008 Château Cheval Noir  (Saint-Émilion)

description: Dark in color, with a series of herbal aromas, this is dense and rich, with fine layers of berry fruits and solid tannins. It has a definite fresh character, with juicy fruit and acidity playing against the dry texture.
title: Mähler-Besse 2008 Château la Couronne  (Saint-Émilion)

description: The alcohol certainly gives the wine richness, but it manages to sustain it well, with superripe black plum and damson flavors, dusty tannins and a powerful texture that rolls richly around the mouth. It leaves a sweet and juicy aftertaste like old-style Rioja.
title: Château de Ferrand 2006  Saint-Émilion

description: Over 90% Merlot from the valley below the hill of Saint-Émilion gives this soft and supple wine. Its tannins and smoky character are integrated into the bold black fruits and acidity. This rich wine will develop relatively quickly. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Yon Lavallade 2015  Saint-Émilion

description: This wine comes from the lower vineyards of Château Quintus. It is fruity, soft and with balanced black fruits and tannins. Spice and hints of wood aging add extra flavor to the wine. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Quintus 2015 Saint-Émilion de Quintus  (Saint-Émilion)

description: Situated to the east of the village of Saint-Émilion, overlooking the Dordogne Valley, this estate has produced a ripe wine in this fruity vintage. With some solid tannins to back up the generous black fruits, it is still young, so best wait to drink until 2019.
title: Château Montlisse 2014  Saint-Émilion

description: While this wine still has the firm, tannic core typical of this vintage, it also has a mature character that shows it's ready to drink. Dry tannins and a ripe, spicy character mingle on the palate. Drink now.
title: Château Valade 2011 L'Etendard de Château Valade  (Saint-Émilion)

description: The second wine of Château Fonplégade is dark, brooding, powerful. There are sweet chocolate and spice flavors that  even manage to dominate the solid, ripe black berry fruits. Certainly rich, it misses the freshness of acidity.
title: Château Fonplégade 2005 Fleur de Fonplégade  (Saint-Émilion)

description: Still young, still forming its tannin and fruit balance, this is likely to turn into a strongly structured wine. The black fruits are in place, the dry tannic core is dense, and, at this stage, the acidity is prominent. Give it 3 years.
title: Château Moulin de Lagnet 2005  Saint-Émilion

description: Ripe Merlot pushes through the tight tannins that are still evident in this wine. This dark, dry core dominates initially, and needs time to open up to show the vivid black currant flavors, touched with dried fruits and fresh finishing acidity.
title: Château Teyssier 2006  Saint-Émilion

description: It may only contain 15% Cabernet Franc, but that grape imparts its signature perfume to this firmly dark wine. The tannins are ripe, if dry, the richness full, and the red plum and blackberry flavors are elegantly exuberant.
title: Christian Moueix 2005  Saint-Émilion

description: A dark, extracted wine, loaded with very ripe fruit and dominated by new wood. It is generally soft, maybe missing structure, but certainly a great wine for lovers of ripe, sweet black fruits.
title: Clos Dubreuil 2005  Saint-Émilion

description: This third-generation property of seven acres is close to the village of Saint-Estéphe on the Pez plateau. Fruity and juicy, the wine is beginning to approach maturity. Its tannins and wood aging are still showing although they are beginning to be well integrated. Wait a few years and drink this wine from 2023.
title: Château Graves de Pez 2014  Saint-Estéphe

description: From a mosaic of 90 different scattered parcels, oenologue Georges Pauli has constructed a firm style of wine, with Saint-Estéphe's characteristic tannins and fresh black currant fruits. This is a structured wine, which should certainly age well. Imported by Fruit of the Vines, Inc.
title: Château Lilian Ladouys 2003  Saint-Estéphe

description: A plump and full wine with forest, cedar, cocoa and black fruit aromas. Handsome fruit with earth, plum and carob elements on the palate. Earthy finish of medium length, with some drying tannins. Already drinkable, it should shine even more in two years.
title: Château Haut-Beauséjour 1995  Saint-Estéphe

description: Firmly structured, this dark and dense wine packs a punch of tannins, giving a dry core. The judicious wood-aging supports the black-currant fruitiness that is developing well. It should be ready to drink from 2017.
title: Château Saint-Corbian 2012 Cuvée Tradition  (Saint-Estéphe)

description: There is some good structure here, as befits a Saint-Estéphe, along with intense fruits and ripe blackberry flavors. That makes the wine both very drinkable now and gives it aging for the next two years. The aftertaste with its juicy acidity is already attractive.
title: Producta Vignobles 2011 Château Grand Chemin Monplaisir  (Saint-Estéphe)

description: This wine has a rich core of black fruits, dense tannins and good acidity, offering testimony to the firm character of Saint-Estéphe. Concentrated. it will develop well. Wait until 2018.
title: Château de Côme 2012  Saint-Estéphe

description: A fresh, fruity and sophisticated wine, this offers acidity balanced by dry tannins. It has juicy black currant fruits, hints of mint and a bright, smoky feel. The wine will obviously age, so drink from 2016.
title: Château Arnaud 2011  Saint-Estéphe

description: Projecting firm tannins, this wine has a big, powerful structure: black plum skins, chewy currants and smoky wood flavors. It's still young; keep it for six years.
title: Château Ségur de Cabanac 2008  Saint-Estéphe

description: A spicy, fruity wine, the structure relatively light but firmly dry, with a strong seasoning of black currant fruits. It is fresh, the fruit juicy and vibrant, with an edge of firm wood.
title: Château Lafon-Rochet 2007  Saint-Estéphe

description: This wine is light and fruity, the blackberry flavors dominating the tannins. It has enough fruit to be drinkable almost immediately, although the aftertaste suggests a drier structure. Drink from late 2018, although the wine will be much better from 2021.
title: Belfontaine 2016  Saint-Estéphe

description: Saint-Georges is the smallest of the so-called Saint-Émilion satellite villages within the orbit of Saint-Émilion proper. This wine is on the light side, emphasizing fruit as much as structure, which is not to say it doesn't have tannins and some aging potential. Black-currant fruit and acidity make this wine. Drink soon from 2020.
title: Château Bellone 2015  Saint-Georges-Saint-Émilion

description: Pricey, but pretty darn good, with mint, chocolate and plum notes carried on a medium-bodied frame. Finishes long, with flourishes of black cherries and modest tannins. Drink now-2015. Imported by Royal Wine Corporation.
