description: Anglophiles will enjoy this wine with its royal coat of arms on the label. The wine itself is less grand, although attractive with its black-currant fruits. At the moment, dry tannins are also a strong presence, and they will soften over the next few years. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Victoria 2013  Haut-Médoc

description: Under the same ownership as Château la Dominique in Saint-Émilion, Clément-Pichon has produced a richly juicy 2012. Firm structure underlies the generous fruits, while the acidity and the dry core of tannins promise good aging. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Clément-Pichon 2012  Haut-Médoc

description: Classic Bordeaux in structure, this firm wine has dry tannins that still dominate the black and red berry fruits. However, the fruit that's now in the background will come strongly forward to give a fresh character and plenty of final black currant.
title: Château Lamothe-Bergeron 2012  Haut-Médoc

description: This is the reserve from Château Landat, produced from old vines. It is hugely dry and structured, showing signs of extraction with its bitter chocolate flavors. At the moment, the fruit doesn't stand a chance although over the next five years, it should soften. Wait until 2019.
title: Château Landat 2012 Vieilles Vignes  (Haut-Médoc)

description: This dense wine is full of ripe plum flavors and opulent tannins. Concentrated, it has just the right amount of structure while pushing the fruit and the fresher acidity forward. It's likely to develop well over the medium-term, so drink from 2016.
title: Château La Lauzette 2012  Haut-Médoc

description: This dense, new-wood flavored wine has solid, dusty tannins and concentrated black fruits that are developing well. The wood flavors are prominent at this early stage, but that ripe fruit and the acidity will certainly balance out. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Haut-Logat 2012  Haut-Médoc

description: The wine has a dense structure, ripe black fruits and a smoky character from the wood aging. It's rich, full of tannins cushioned by full-on black plum and berry flavors. Because it feels so full bodied, it's likely to be ready soon. Drink from 2016.
title: Château Tourteran 2012  Haut-Médoc

description: From a Merlot-dominated, 24-acre vineyard this is a strongly mineral wine, with young, dark tannins and a powerful structure. A more juicy, fruity side brings out black currants and berries. Together the structure and the fruit promise good aging. Drink from 2017.
title: Château le Moulin d'Ulysse 2011  Haut-Médoc

description: The wine is closed up at this stage, just showing structure and only hints of dark fruit. However, there is a feeling of power and a dense texture that need time to open up. The result is a wine full of potential, finishing with some juicy fruitiness.
title: Château d'Hanteillan 2011  Haut-Médoc

description: A dark and dense wine, it is full of black juicy fruits and has considerable weight. It shows some bitter extract but this is counterbalanced by the rich, blackberry juice flavors. It should be aged, so drink from 2017.
title: Clos la Bohéme 2011  Haut-Médoc

description: This is a dark, young-colored wine, its purple shade reflecting the dense wood and tannin-laden flavors. It has spice and some bitter extract but these are balanced by ripe blackberry fruits and a rich texture. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Lestage Simon 2011  Haut-Médoc

description: A finely integrated and ripe wine that is full of rich fruits and solid, dusty tannins. It has good concentration, sweet black fruits and great acidity. It will age well; drink from 2017.
title: Château Liversan 2011  Haut-Médoc

description: This exotic, spicy wine's wood flavors give it a lively character. This is a medium-bodied wine, not heavy in any sense, its fruitiness and attractive acidity producing a wine that will soon be ready to drink.
title: Château Larose-Trintaudon 2011  Haut-Médoc

description: A firm and concentrated wine, this is dark and full bodied. It shows the superripe fruit produced by the 2009 vintage. Attractively full and juicy, it has extra weight and a dark chocolate flavor, plus a spicy finish. Age for 2-3 years.
title: Château Bibian 2009  Haut-Médoc

description: Dark in color-partly from the blend's 20% Petit Verdot-this wood-aged wine is laden with an extracted toast flavor and tannins. It is very concentrated, with a flavor of black plum skin and berry-like acidity that contribute to its density.
title: Château Belle-Vue 2010  Haut-Médoc

description: By Médoc standards, this 7-acre vineyard is small, with a production of 1,150 cases. The powerful blackberry flavor is sweetened by dark plum and licorice notes, structured with new wood influence and firm tannins. There is a juicy finish, and the tannins promise long-term aging.
title: Clos la Bohéme 2010  Haut-Médoc

description: Now mature, this is a powerful wine for the vintage. It has a spice note, plus tannins that are still present and likely to develop further. The flavors of truffle, gamy beef and beet are are testaments to the age of this wine. It needs to be consumed over the next year.
title: Bernard Magrez 2004 Château la Temperance  (Haut-Médoc)

description: A rich, fruity wine, this shows a jammy blackberry flavor, with just the right balancing acidity. Wood aging lends this wine a polished feel, and the tannins are comfortably cushioned by the ripe fruit. It has the richness of the vintage while still maintaining elegance.
title: Château Laride 2009  Haut-Médoc

description: The reserve wine from Lamothe-Cissac is now a wine that is well on the way to maturity. It has a leathery texture that's well integrated with wood and mushroom flavors. The acidity is just in the background. Drink now or over the next 3-4 years.
title: Château Lamothe-Cissac 2008 Vieilles Vignes  (Haut-Médoc)

description: While youthful tannins play an important part in this dense wine, so does the black fruit character. It's balanced, with the wood toast adding extra complexity. Ripe, while structured, it will age over several years.
title: Château Bellevue Canterrane 2010  Haut-Médoc

description: Owned by renowned wine consultant Jacques Boissenot (advisor to most of the Bordeaux first growths), this should be exemplary-and it is. It is pure black currant fruit, understated yet beautifully balanced. The acidity pierces through the dry fruit tannins. The wine finishes with just a hint of wood.
title: Château les Vimiéres 2008  Haut-Médoc

description: Ripe wine, finely balanced with good acidity giving the concentrated black currant fruit a bright character. Tannins show well, a dry core layered with juicy fruit. Age for 2-4 years.
title: Château Tour de Goua 2009 Cuvée les Aubarédes  (Haut-Médoc)

description: Richly juicy wine, with black plum and damson fruits surrounded by layers of firm, dry tannins. It is structured, intense, the fruit laced with satisfying acidity.
title: Château Landat 2006  Haut-Médoc

description: Wood and solid fruit give the character of this wine. It has a dense, tannic and dusty fruit texture. Fruit flavors show a juicy black cherry character, underlined with licorice and tight acidity.
title: Château de Villegeorge 2008  Haut-Médoc

description: Good firm tannins, with ripe blackberry jam flavors, are followed by some spice from wood. This is a well-structured wine, its elements in place. The dry edge is finally dominant, and it probably needs 2-3 years aging.
title: Château Paloumey 2007  Haut-Médoc

description: Cool, calm wine, its fruit and tannins kept nicely in check. There is a classic feel here, square and elegant. The berry fruits are bright, with a spurt of sweet and sour acidity. Age for 3-4 years.
title: Château Cambon la Pelouse 2007  Haut-Médoc

description: A firm, spicy wine, its fruit and tannins showing the character of the vintage, but also with some weight. The tannins are dense rather than hard and the berry fruits are juicy, but manage to keep high acidity at bay. A success.
title: Mähler-Besse 2007 Château d'Arche  (Haut-Médoc)

description: The continuing improvement at classed growth Camensac under the ownership of the Merlaut family (Chasse-Spleen, Citran, etc) is apparent even in the lesser vintage of 2007. The structure hangs well with the stalky but solid black berry fruit, the acidity a pure streak through it. Age over 4-5 years.
title: Château de Camensac 2007  Haut-Médoc

description: A finely structured wine, the wood well integrated into elegant firm fruit tannins and spice. Red fruit flavors fit well with the dry element, giving a wine with depth of flavor. Worth aging for 2-3 years.
title: Château Liversan 2007  Haut-Médoc

description: A wine that has some richness, with blackberry fruits and a fine balance with wood and fruit tannins. It has good structure, but the fruit also offers pleasure in 2-3 years.
title: Château Sénéjac 2007  Haut-Médoc

description: This wine boasts dry, old-school tannins that bracket the black currant fruit on the palate. It will soften as it matures to deliver crisp fruit and cleaner tannins. Drink from 2023.
title: Château d'Arcins 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: This wine, dominated by ripe Cabernet Sauvignon, is well structured, richly tannic and likely to age well. A firm underlay of dry tannins supports the rich fruit and acidity. It has a crisp final texture. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Bel Air 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: The vines of this 50-acre estate, close to Listrac, have produced a rich wine in this vintage. With its spice and toast character and ripe berry fruits coming together nicely, the wine will develop well. Its potential is for medium-term aging, meaning it will be ready to drink from 2023.
title: Château Bibian 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: This family-owned estate has produced a dark and dense wine. With plenty of ripe berry fruits and good acidity, it is well proportioned, juicy and firm. Perfumed black currants and a sense of balance are hallmarks of this wine. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Balac 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: This property, now owned by the Antoine Moeuix negociant firm, has made a rich wine with ripe tannins that support the generous black-currant fruits. The structure is dense although there is clear light through the tannins to the fruit. It needs to age further, so drink from 2021.
title: Château Liversan 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: This wine, with its exuberant black fruits, is very young. But it is already deliciously fruity, with a backdrop of tannins. The brightness, rich texture, poised acidity and black-currant flavors promise a good future. Drink from 2020.
title: Château le Chêne 2016  Haut-Médoc

description: Situated in the north of the Haut-Médoc, close to Saint-Estéphe, this vineyard has been owned by the Fabre family since 1982. This vintage is rich, with an interesting proportion of Petit Verdot in the blend to give color and structure. It's ripe with black-currant and berry fruits, with a firm aftertaste. Drink from 2022.
title: Château la Tonnelle 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: Dense, dark wine, with good black plum, fig, coffee and sweet raisin flavors. The ripe tannins fit well into this fruit mélange, with definite richness from new wood. There is good, juicy power here, as the wine finishes well with both dry tannin and fresh acidity.
title: Château Barreyres 2006  Haut-Médoc

description: A Cabernet Sauvignon-dominated wine, which reveals great structure to go with its black berry fruits. American Daren Miller, married to a Bordeaux native, has been involved in the restoration of this property in the Médoc, producing a classic wine, that pays great respect to its origins.
title: Château Haut Beyzac 2005  Haut-Médoc

description: A new wood aged selection of vines from Château Haut Beyzac, a property being restored by Pennsylvanian Daren Miller and his French in-laws. It is delicious, elegant, offering classic black currant flavors of Bordeaux, but with an extra depth and richness. Fine, elegant acidity to finish.
title: Château Haut Beyzac 2005 I Second Haut Beyzac  (Haut-Médoc)

description: A wine that is dominated by big, dense tannins. The black currant fruits come through with a stalky character. As it opens in the mouth, the wine shows some richness, along with its tannins, a hint of wood giving a smooth, elegant edge to the finish. It does need aging-four to five years.
title: Château Paloumey 2006  Haut-Médoc

description: This is Barton & Guestier's home vineyard and, in 2006, it has produced a finely crafted wine. The balance is all there, with ripe red berry fruits and cranberry juice adding to the firm, dark core of tannins. It is worth aging  for two to three years but is certainly drinkable now.
title: Château Magnol 2006  Haut-Médoc

description: Rich and structured, this is a sturdy wine that shows good dry fruit tannins as well as wood. The blackberry fruit is open, ripe, giving a good juicy character and depth of flavor. This is a wine for 2-3 years' aging.
title: Château Liversan 2006  Haut-Médoc

description: You get dense, concentrated fruit with this packed wine. It has the right tannins balancing with wood and acidity, blackberry fruits, some red berries, freshness and a ripe finish. A good, structured Bordeaux.
title: Château Barreyres 2005  Haut-Médoc

description: From a small five-acre vineyard owned by actor Gérard Depardieu. The fruit may be from superripe 2003 grapes, but there is a some restraint here, keeping the juicy opulence in balance with the freshness, excellent tannic structure and the open, lively aftertaste.
title: Ma Verité 2003  Haut-Médoc

description: Dominated by 80% Merlot, this wine is smooth, ripe and generous. Gentle tannins are balanced with rich berry and black-currant fruit, kept crisp by acidity. With its smooth texture, the wine is developing fast and will be ready to drink from 2019.
title: Clos des Grands Moines 2015  Lalande de Pomerol

description: This wine, hugely rich and packed with tannins, has equally powerful black fruits. Its rich texture and blackberry and licorice flavors will need considerable time to integrate fully. The estate, which dates to 1770, is now under the same ownership as Château de Chambrun. Drink this wine from 2022.
title: Château Moncets 2015  Lalande de Pomerol

description: Packed with ripe Merlot fruit, this is a dense wine. It has impressive structure and great acidity to cut through the dark fruit. Rich and full in the mouth, this will be a solid fine wine from 2020.
title: Domaine des Sabines 2014  Lalande de Pomerol

description: Produced from young vines at Château Siaurac, the wine, dominated by 90% Merlot, is generous, approachable and ripe. It was matured in tank rather than wood, allowing the black fruits to come through strongly. The aftertaste brings out fruitiness as much as the gentle tannins.
title: Château Siaurac 2014 Plaisir de Siaurac  (Lalande de Pomerol)

description: A blend of 75% Merlot with 25% Cabernet Franc, the wine has richness. It also has the firm dry tannins that are typical of the vintage. It is dry and solid with its black-currant fruits still developing. It needs to age further, so wait until 2018.
title: Château Bourseau 2011  Lalande de Pomerol

description: This is a super Cuvée from Bourseau with dense dark extracted tannins and concentrated fruits. It is rich, almost too rich, full of powerful fruits, black plum skins and a young firm structure. It will remain dry and tannic for several more years, so don't drink before 2020.
title: Château Bourseau 2011 La Croix de Bourseau  (Lalande de Pomerol)

description: In this Merlot-dominated wine, powerful wood flavors still show strongly against the fresh, juicy black-currant and berry fruits. As this combination ages, it will produce a ripe, full and always fruity wine with strong final acidity. Drink from 2018.
title: Château la Croix Romane 2012  Lalande de Pomerol

description: This hugely ripe Merlot has created a monster of a wine, heavily laden with bitter coffee extraction as well as very ripe black plum fruits. Big and concentrated, this is a wine to be enjoyed for its profusion and excess.
title: Château Siaurac 2010  Lalande de Pomerol

description: A ripe, balanced wine this is maturing well. It has a black plum note to go with the underlying tannins. Rich juicy flavors join notes of spice and wood, leading onto the firm finish. Age for another two years.
title: Domaine Pont de Guestres 2008  Lalande de Pomerol

description: Siaurac, at 153 acres, is the largest estate in Lalande de Pomerol. The 2007 shows the relative lightness of the vintage, but boosts it up with chocolate and dark plum flavors. The wine finishes freshly, but still with tight tannins.
title: Château Siaurac 2007  Lalande de Pomerol

description: Broad tannins coupled with the berry fruits of the vintage have produced a bright wine with just the right firm structure. It is a rich wine, but also one showing elegance and restraint. That makes for a great wine for food, with a crisp aftertaste and good acidity. Drink from late 2018.
title: Château Vieux Chaigneau 2014  Lalande de Pomerol

description: A rich Merlot-driven wine, smoothly polished by new wood. Flavors of mint mingle with sweet tannins and black berry fruits. There is a fine, smoky edge as well to this wine, which would certainly benefit from 3-4 years' aging.
title: Château de Bel-Air 2006  Lalande de Pomerol

description: This is the first vintage under its new owner, the American Stephen Adams. It's relatively soft, with black currant fruits, given a delicious lift by some tight tannins. The acidity gives freshness, a zap to the dry, firm finish.
title: Château de Bel-Air 2005  Lalande de Pomerol

description: The estate belongs to the Borie family, one of the grand names of Bordeaux, with the wine making done by the team of Château Ducru-Beaucaillou in Saint-Julien. The result is an aromatic, balanced wine that is both structured and fruity. It has fine tannins, black currant fruit and a perfumed aftertaste.
title: Château Ducluzeau 2012  Listrac-Médoc

description: This wine comes from one of a group of wineries with vines in the small area north of Listrac called Le Fourcas. It's packed with red fruits and juicy acidity. The dominant Merlot gives a bold, rich texture backed up by the more structured Cabernets. It will develop quickly and be ready from 2017.
title: Château Fourcas Dupré 2012  Listrac-Médoc

description: This well-made, ripe and fruity wine has soft tannins that are already well integrated with the red-berry fruits. Acidity keeps it all fresh and suggests the wine could age over the medium-term. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Lestage 2013  Listrac-Médoc

description: This Merlot-dominant wine is dark and dense. The dry tannins and wood aging give spice as much as fruit at this stage. A more juicy black currant-flavored element should assert itself with time, so drink from 2018.
title: Château Reverdi 2012  Listrac-Médoc

description: Often richer than its stablemate, Château Fonréaud, Lestage in 2012 also has more obvious wood aging flavors. It's big and concentrated, dominated by smoky tannins. It's going to develop into a rich wine, packed with blackberry flavors and always a dry core.
title: Château Lestage 2012  Listrac-Médoc

description: A wine with structure, this achieves balance with its black currant flavor and acidity. It's lined firmly with tannins that bring a dry and texture to this solid, age-worthy bottle. Give it at least five years.
title: Château Saransot-Dupré 2009  Listrac-Médoc

description: At five years old, this wine is still young, with firm, extracted tannins still in place. They will not completely go, and this solid wine will remain densely structured. On the other hand, the black-currant fruit is there, adding a further element to the wine. It's a food wine. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Donissan 2014  Listrac-Médoc

description: The 48% Cabernet Franc in this wine gives it a smoky perfume. Dry and still firm, the structure offers ripe tannins, hints of wood aging and fragrant blackberry fruits. The wine needs to age a little longer, so drink from 2020.
title: Château de Lussac 2014 Cuvée Bellevue  (Lussac Saint-Émilion)

description: Lussac is one of the so-called satellites of Saint-Emilion (villages that attach the magic Saint-Emilion name to their own). But it does have many attractive wines that emulate Saint-Emilion in every way except the high price. This wine, a blend of 80% Merlot and 20% Cabernet Franc, with a combination of dry austere blackcurrant fruit and sweet tannins, has that evocative cigar box, tobacco flavor that marks out a good Saint-Emilion. It finishes dry, tannic and demanding either decanting or a few years' aging, but also ready to drink with food this holiday season.
title: Château Michel de Vert 2003  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: Dominated by Merlot, this is big, ripe wine. It still has the youthful tannic structure, but it also has so much good berry fruitiness. Rich, juicy with acidity and fresh black currants, it will benefit from some aging. Drink from 2016.
title: Producta Vignobles 2011 Château Lagrange  (Lussac Saint-Émilion)

description: The 74 acres of Bel-Air have produced a firm while juicy wine packed with both tannins and ripe blackberry fruits. The structure and ripe Merlot combine easily and suggest good aging. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Bel-Air 2012  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: A solid, structured wine, showing the fine tannins of the vintage along with ripe berry fruits. It has weight, acidity, without pushing the alcohol forward, remaining in balance. Age this wine for 3-4 years.
title: Château Bel-Air 2010  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: While the wine has some richness, it is also firmly structured, with a minerally severity from its tight tannins. Under the surface, there is a fruity character that's dominated by a juicy black-currant flavor.
title: Château Bel-Air 2009  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: This is a complex wine that shows sweet berry fruits, ripe tannins and new wood flavors. It is dense and chewy while also being full of rich fruits. This is a wine for aging, although its smooth character suggests it will age relatively quickly.
title: Château la Jorine 2009  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: This dense wine from the so-called Saint-Émilion satellite village of Lussac has plenty of the richness of the vintage as well as ripe berry fruits and generously integrated tannins. With plenty of black fruits at the end, the wine will age well. Drink from 2021.
title: Producta Vignobles 2015 Les Clés de Lussac  (Lussac Saint-Émilion)

description: Ripe Merlot makes its generous mark in this rich, fruity wine. It has structure and dense tannins as well as juicy black-currant fruits. The richness is not excessive, accompanying this core of tannins. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Haut-Piquat 2015  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: Taking advantage of the very ripe grapes of 2003, Bernard Magrez's winemakers pulled all the richness out of the fruit and into this intensely sweet, dark wine, with its black plums and fig flavors. The wood is all around this fruit, dense and spicy.
title: Château la Croix de l'Esperance 2003  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: A rich, succulent wine, full of ripe black currant and spice flavors, wrapped around a core of dry tannins. This is a wine that needs time to develop, but with its toast and other wood flavors and its weighty fruit, it should show well in five years.
title: Château Croix de Rambeau 2004  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: Cantenac-Brown has been tending to classic Margaux delicacy in recent years, but this 2003 is an exception. It is round and full of ripe blackberry fruits, with good tannins and is likely to develop well. Imported by Diageo Chateau & Estates.
title: Château Cantenac Brown 2003  Margaux

description: This chateau has a fine and deserved reputation, as this powerful but elegant 2003 shows. It has all the sophistication of Margaux, along with some lightness that balances the dry tannins. Imported by Vignobles De France.
title: Château Monbrison 2003  Margaux

description: Brane-Cantenac's natural elegance, at the heart of Margaux, doesn't seem to have survived 2003 as well as some other properties, despite the initial favorable impression at barrel tasting time. That is to say that the fruit is very generous, juicy almost, but its ripeness seems out of proportion to the soft tannins and sweet aftertaste. Other current vintages, particularly 2001 and 2004, have been better. Imported by Diageo Chateau & Estates.
title: Château Brane-Cantenac 2003  Margaux

description: Angludet is the story of an estate that has been built up painstakingly over several decades. The Sichels, whose family home this is, make very satisfying wines, which are always good values. The 2001, with its good structure, its black fruits and its sympathetic use of wood, has balance and elegance. Ripe fruits with tobacco aromas complete the package.
title: Château d'Angludet 2001  Margaux

description: Huge investment is paying off at Labegorce. And it has not resulted in a wine that is simply modern in style. For here the new wood is well integrated, the fruit is structured, and never too extracted, and the ripeness also has layers of Bordeaux dryness.
title: Château Labégorce Margaux 2001  Margaux

description: One of the many Margaux estates under the control of the Lurton family, this is a classic wine, with dry wood and dark tannins, flavors of black currants and light acidity. There is no mistaking this as Bordeaux, with its serious, ageworthy fruits and tannins.
title: Chateau Desmirail 2001  Margaux

description: Attractive, fresh flavors with ripe, red fruits make this wine very forward and immediate. It does lack some concentration, but the ripe fruit and delicate perfumes will make it beautifully drinkable in five years.
title: Château d'Angludet 2000  Margaux

description: This is not as big or as concentrated as many 2000s. But it has elegance and style, along with fine, ripe perfumed fruit and attractive, balancing acidity. Give this wine at least 8 years before drinking.
title: Château Siran 2000  Margaux

description: This second wine of Labégorce Margaux is named after the former neighboring estate Labégorce Zédé that was amalgamated after the 2009 vintage. This is a ripe wine, full of the fruit of the vintage as well as having a firm dry tannic structure that will allow it to age. With juicy blackberry fruits still so youthful, it is going to be ready drink from 2019.
title: Château Labégorce Margaux 2012 Zédé de Labégorce  (Margaux)

description: The second wine of classed growth Rauzan-Gassies in Margaux is ripe, soft with touches of licorice, wood aging and spice. It has attractive, forward red-berry flavors and the tannins of the 65% Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend. It is ready to drink.
title: Château Rauzan-Gassies 2011 Gassies  (Margaux)

description: Crisp fruit dominates this second wine from Durfort Vivens. It has tannins, tight acidity as well as the potential for further aging. Spice and wood flavors finish the wine on a firm note. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Durfort-Vivens 2011 Vivens  (Margaux)

description: This wine is full of bright fruit and attractive acidity. It's been made to take advantage of the fruitiness of the year and is likely to develop quickly. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Ferriére 2013  Margaux

description: Perfumed wood dominates this wine, giving it structure and tannins. Juicy red fruits are still submerged beneath this welter of dryness. The wine needs time to integrate. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Mongravey 2013  Margaux

description: Like many wines from Marie-Laure Lurton, this is dry and shows its firm tannic and wood character. Here the wood verges on too much, giving an austere, hard character. However, the black currant fruit will come through, giving a dry wine that will have some richness. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Tour de Bessan 2012  Margaux

description: This structured wine has firm tannins and a solid core of wood-aging flavors. At the same time it shows some of the style of Margaux with its balanced acidity and ripe berry fruits. Age until at least 2018.
title: Château Paveil de Luze 2012  Margaux

description: On the lean side, with a layered concentrated wood structure. The wine has weight along with dryness, although the fruit is harder to discern.
title: Château Siran 2009  Margaux

description: The wine has weight, is warm and spicy, with bold fruit flavors. A fine wine from Angludet, it is ripe, the wood judiciously balanced, finishing with tight acidity.
title: Château d'Angludet 2009  Margaux

description: With its high wood flavors and aromas of mint, this sets out to be a modern, extracted style of wine. But it has the lightness of Margaux in 2007, the Cabernet tannins soft and open. It already has good balance, suggesting it is not for long aging.
title: Château d'Issan 2007  Margaux

description: A wine that emphasizes the fruity character of the year, putting aside any missing tannins. Wood still dominates the fruit, giving spice and bitter chocolate flavors, but the green edge present in the futures tasting has gone, to give final cranberry and black currant freshness.
title: Château Monbrison 2007  Margaux

description: A wine that has richness, with acidity, layers of spice and black currant fruit flavors. The dominant cassis gives elegance, and already a forward balance of fruit and wood.
title: Château Margaux 2007 Pavillon Rouge de Château Margaux  (Margaux)

description: Piled high with new wood, dark-chocolate flavors and dryness, this wine will be a tough call for many years. It will show better, although the over-indulgent use of wood will likely always keep it dry.
title: Château Desmirail 2015  Margaux

description: The second wine of Château Potensac, and under the same ownership as Château Léoville Las Cases, this is an impressive wine in its own right, packed with very ripe fruit, but still preserving the outline and structure of a solid Médoc. There is a wood element, but it is mainly the luscious black fruit that stands out in this wine. Imported by Diageo Chateau & Estates.
title: Château Potensac 2003 Chapelle de Potensac  (Médoc)

description: Although this youthful wine has obviously been in plenty of wood, it has the weight to reveal a promising future. So while the spice and toastiness are present now, they will soon integrate with the fine tannins and blackberry fruits. Drink this from 2019.
title: Château Bellerive 2014  Médoc

description: From one of the estates owned by the Pagés family in the northern Médoc, the wine is spicy and rich with tannins and blackberry fruit. As a contrast, it is shot through with attractive acidity that is a character of the year. The wine will be ready to drink from 2019.
title: Château la Roque de By 2014  Médoc

description: A smooth and ripe wine produced by the team of Cos d'Estournel. It is full and rich with black-plum fruits and velvet tannins. With fine acidity at the back, it has kept its freshness. Drink from 2022.
title: Goulée 2014 Goulée de Cos d'Estournel  (Médoc)

description: From vineyards close to the Gironde estuary, this estate has produced a bright and fruity wine dominated by Cabernet Sauvignon. That gives both a firm dry tannic structure and crisp black-currant fruit. The wine will develop over the next few years and should be drunk from 2019.
title: Château Lousteauneuf 2014  Médoc

description: This is a lush succulent wine. It is full of ripe blackberry and black-plum fruits that are rich and superripe. Wood aging gives toast while licorice and bitter coffee flavors speak of some extraction. It is full-blown wine-sweet and juicy at the end.
title: Bernard Magrez 2014 Château Pérenne  (Médoc)

description: This is a ripe wine that also has a light touch. That gives black-currant fruit and tannins along with a poised structure and attractive crisp acidity. The Cabernet Sauvignon fruit dominates while also giving the wine a dry core. Drink this stylish wine from 2019.
title: Château Escot 2012  Médoc

description: This 16th century chateau with towers is in the northern Médoc. The wine is spicy with the wood aging still showing. At the same time, the ripe black-currant fruit is developing well and as it ages further, the wine will become finely balanced. With 60% Cabernet in the blend, this is a wine for the long term. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Tour Prignac 2014  Médoc

description: With vines close to the Garonne estuary, this estate benefits from a warm microclimate. In 2010, that gave a high alcohol wine that shows weight and concentration. It is dense, developing its tannins and rich black-plum fruits well. The alcohol does show in a burnt edge which is the downside of this otherwise finely balanced, maturing wine. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Pontey 2010  Médoc

description: This is a ripe concentrated wine, full of black-currant fruit and dense tannins. The two balance each other giving a wine that has weight and a medium-term future. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Bois Cardon 2012  Médoc

description: Aging in wood for 18 months has brought out the richness of this generous wine. It has black-currant acidity that is balanced by the tarry tannins and smoky character. Rich and now in equilibrium, this wine is ready to drink.
title: Château Hourbanon 2009  Médoc

description: Ripe and juicy, this wine is soft, generous and full of rich, while very fresh fruits. It has black-currant acidity, a touch of spice and a perfumed aftertaste. Drink from 2017.
title: Goulée 2013  Médoc

description: This is a rich, densely tannic wine with dark-hued blackberry fruits and ripe acidity. It is concentrated, still very firm while just beginning to show its full-bodied character. Wait until 2018.
title: Château la Tour de By 2011  Médoc

description: Rich, juicy and structured, this firm wine has great power and concentration along with a dark, dry core. It's almost too much of a good thing, very flamboyant and ripe. It still needs to age to be fully balanced.
title: Château le Reysse 2010  Médoc

description: Unusually for the Médoc, this is a blend of Merlot and Cabernet Franc, rather than Sauvignon. That explains the lightly perfumed character of this full, still very tannic wine. It's structured and concentrated with a dry center and the potential of bright red fruits later. The wine needs aging, drink from 2016.
title: Producta Vignobles 2011 Château la Grave  (Médoc)

description: With a dominance of Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend, this structured and firm wine has a dry, dusty character lightened by black currant fruitiness. The aftertaste, with its good mix of fruit and acidity shows a wine that's likely to be ready to drink from 2016.
title: Cheval Quancard 2012 1844  (Médoc)

description: Richness combines well with the ripe blackberry fruits and acidity, producing a wine that's developing a full, firm character led by fruit tannins and just a touch of wood. It needs to age, so drink from 2017.
title: Château de Panigon 2012  Médoc

description: Layers of new wood dominate this solid wine, giving a dusty, toasty, burnt character that needs to blow away. The wine though has the weight to develop well with its ripe, juicy black fruit flavors. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Vieux Robin 2012  Médoc

description: Serious amounts of new wood dominate this still young wine. It has weight and there is great juicy black currant fruit underneath the dry wood character. Once it opens up again, this is going to be a delicious, structured wine. Drink from 2016.
title: Château Grand Bertin de Saint Clair 2010  Médoc
winery: Château Grand Bertin de Saint Clair

description: A rich, sweetly fruity wine, its ripe black plum fruit balanced by fine acidity and layered with wood. It is a solid and dense wine, firm and with great juiciness. Likely to age well for 4-5 years.
title: Jean-Michel Cazes 2011 Réserve  (Médoc)

description: Rich and smooth, this is a good example of the sumptuous 2009 vintage. It is soft, ripe with blackberry and red plum fruits. It is already developing well. It's a medium-term wine, already juicy and drinkable.
title: Château le Temple 2009  Médoc

description: Dark and extracted, this has firm, dry tannins. It's hard edged, but the potential of the black currant fruit is apparent. Give this structured wine at least five years for the rich fruit to surface.
title: Château Clément Saint-Jean 2010  Médoc

description: With rich fruit that is balanced by tight acidity, this shows both the structure and the fragrant red berry flavor of the vintage. The acids cut through the wine to shape its freshness, highlighting its dark tannins. It needs to age for 4-5 years.
title: Château Pierre de Montignac 2010  Médoc

description: On the austere side, with a firm and dry tannic structure, this represents the classic style of Bordeaux. It has black currant fruit and a mineral edge, with a severe structure that demands to be aged.
title: Château Greysac 2010  Médoc

description: Initially dry and tannic, the wine shows dark fruits with blueberry flavors, smoke and spice. It is rich and dense, already with the fruit right up front. Drink now or better age.
title: Château Lacombe Noaillac 2009  Médoc

description: With spicy wood and mint aromas, the wine has ripe blackberry fruit, sweet tannins and some fine concentrated dark flavors. It is structured with a dry core of acidity and fruit skins. Ready to drink, but worth aging.
title: Château Beauvillage 2008  Médoc

description: This is a solid wine that has a mineral edge and some austerity. At the same time, it has weight that will stand it in good stead as it develops. Very dry, but with a streak of juiciness.
title: Château Griviére 2008  Médoc

description: This is a concentrated, balanced, sweetly juicy wine, benefiting from wood and ripe black fig and plum flavors. It has fine ripe tannins that support the freshly juicy fruits. Ready to drink, but will age over 2-3 years.
title: Château La Cardonne 2007  Médoc

description: One of a number of estates owned by the Pagés family in the northern Médoc, this property has produced a wood-laden wine, yet one that is also full of ripe fruit. Young at the moment and with the toasty character still prominent, this wine will take its time to bring out the potential of the blackberries and acidity. They are there and will be show best from 2023.
title: Château la Roque de By 2015  Médoc

description: With a high percentage of Merlot, this is a ripe, juicy and red-fruit-flavored wine. It is soft, with the tannins already well integrated into the plush fruit. This rich, generous wine will be ready to drink from 2022.
title: Château Labadie 2015  Médoc

description: This Bouey estate, with its historic 18th-century tower, is named for an ancestor. This wine is richly endowed, structured and with a solid core of tannins. The black-currant fruit around the tannins is balanced, ripe and likely to age along with the wood and tannic structure. Drink from 2021.
title: Château la France Delhomme 2015  Médoc

description: With a blast of Petit Verdot in the blend (15%, not typical Médoc), this structured, toasty wine revels in its ripe tannins. It is packed with fruit, with a dry core that will allow it to age. Drink the wine from 2024.
title: Château l'Argenteyre 2015  Médoc

description: This is a structured northern-Médoc wine with good aging potential from Jean-Jacques Baudoux. With its tannins well in play, it has a dry core that is emphasized by the spice and toast from wood aging. The wine is likely to need some time, so drink from 2022.
title: Château Cangruey 2015  Médoc

description: This is a rich wine, generous with ripe berry fruit. Produced in the northern Médoc, it holds equal quantities of Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon, giving both juicy fruits and a firm structure that will allow the wine to age. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Amour 2015  Médoc

description: This wine is ripe, juicy and packed with black-currant fruits. Its tannins and wood aging are playing a good supporting role. Generous and full, this juicy wine, from a 61-acre estate, will age well. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Poitevin 2015  Médoc

description: This wine is firm, with a dry core that will take time to soften. But that will happen, because of the ripe black-currant fruit that lies underneath the tannic structure, giving a juicy potential to this rich wine. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Lousteauneuf 2015  Médoc

description: Fine wood flavors, balancing with black berry fruits, red plums and some soft chocolate and vanilla. The tannins play a fine supporting role, leaving the vivacious fruit, with its delicious juicy character, to have the final word.
title: Château Tour Prignac 2005  Médoc

description: Rich black-currant fruits mingle with dusty, dry tannins in this young wine. A ripe, jammy character comes from the 85% Merlot in the blend. Fruity and lifted by acidity, the wine needs to age. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Coucy 2016  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: From a vineyard dating back to the 15th-century, this is an almost pure Merlot wine. It is ripe, juicy and with a good balance between acidity and red fruits. The tannins are already soft, allowing the fruitiness to shine. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Teyssier 2014  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: The origins of this estate date back to a medieval Benedictine monastery. Today, the 29-acre estate has produced a rich-almost too rich-wine. Its jammy blackberry fruits are spoiled by the hint of pepper that comes from the alcohol. Still, the fruit is ripe and dense with a backing of firm tannins. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Faizeau 2014 Sélection Vieilles Vignes  (Montagne-Saint-Émilion)

description: Full of bright black-currant fruit, this wine shows its young fruitiness, backed by a dry core of tannins and ample acidity. With its structure and spicy wood flavors, it will develop into a complex, dense wine. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Tour Bayard 2014  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: Mint and eucalypt aromas set the scene for a modern, polished wine, packed with wood tannins as well as ripe black fruits. Currently, the tannins are winning giving a wine that is dark, structured and dry. So give it at least five years.
title: Château Faizeau 2010 Sélection Vieilles Vignes  (Montagne-Saint-Émilion)

description: Full and ripe, the wine's lush texture demonstrates the dominance of Merlot. It also has a dense, tannic character that pushes through the rich fruit, lending balance and aging potential. Keep this for at least five years.
title: Château Croix de Mission 2010  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: Ripe and extracted, this shows more of a bitter chocolate note than a fruit flavor. It has a very dry, firmly tannic character, with a dark, smoky feel. Powerful and concentrated, its pepper and spice tones accompany the note of black plum skin. Expect this to soften slowly over 4-5 years.
title: Château Plaisance 2010  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: Far too young to even consider drinking, this is a wine whose potential comes from its rich, round, concentrated black fruits and its dense tannins. It's chewy and chunky; age for at least four years.
title: Château Vieux Montagne 2011  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: Firm and austere, this shows the structured side of the vintage. The wine has weight and rich fruit, giving it the promise of good aging. Give this at least two years to soften.
title: Horeau-Beylot 2010 Château la Fleur  (Montagne-Saint-Émilion)

description: Structure and ripe fruit go well together in this generous wine. Wood aging gives a toasty edge as well as flavors of bitter coffee and smokiness. Black-currant fruit is right there. The wine needs good aging, so don't drink before 2021.
title: Château Piron 2016  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: This small, seven-acre property has an unusually high (20%) proportion of Petit Verdot in its wine, giving it big color and structure. Ripe black currant fruits balance the tannins. Drink from 2018.
title: Château la Garricq 2013  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: Layers of smooth, new-wood flavors dominate this full wine. Dark chocolate and black plum flavors show the wood and the fruit of the wine. It's already concentrated and richer than many wines in the vintage. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Branas Grand Poujeaux 2012  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: Ripe, full in the mouth and with a smooth, already silky texture, this is a generous wine. Its ripe blackberry fruits are juicy, while the tannins are soft and cushioned by the ripe fruits. This is a wine that will develop well, so drink from 2016.
title: Château Brillette 2011  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: Made by the team from Château Chasse-Spleen, this elegant, smooth wine has deceptively firm tannins. The wine is dense, structured with plenty of juicy black currant fruits to balance. It will age, so don't drink before 2018.
title: Château Gressier Grand Poujeaux 2011  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: This 20-acre vineyard produces a wine dominated by Merlot, lending the wine a smooth texture. The wine is rich with ripe plum flavors and only gentle tannins. It will age well over the medium-term, so drink from 2016.
title: Château Guitignan 2011  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: This is concentrated, rich, full of blackberry fruits and layered with just the right balance of tannins. Chocolate and sweet fruits are given point by toast and an edge of spice.
title: Château la Graviére Grand Poujeaux 2009  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: Deeply embedded in firm tannins, this is a wine for aging. There is plenty of mineral, black currant and plum juice fruit, with a fine juicy element as well as acidity. It is balanced and harmonious, a keeper for 5-6 years.
title: Château Dutruch Grand Poujeaux 2008  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: Under the control of the winemaking team of Lafite, this estate is on a roll. This is a beautifully balanced wine, with complexity, richness and cassis, figs and black plums. It is developing relatively quickly, and will be ready to drink in two to three years. Imported by Diageo Chateau & Estates.
title: Château Duhart-Milon 2003  Pauillac

description: A great success for this fifth growth, run by Claire Villars. The 2003 is velvety, rounded, beautifully balanced. It is not a densely powerful wine, showing more elegance and seduction. It is already developing, and should be ready to drink in four or five years, maybe less. Imported by Diageo Chateau & Estates.
title: Château Haut Bages Libéral 2003  Pauillac

description: This chateau, owned by one of the old Bordeaux families, the Bories, has only recently begun to gain the stature its vineyard, in the south of Pauillac, demands. This '03 is still very tight, packed with dark, tannic fruits, and dominated by a dense layer of wood. The price is still reasonable, which makes this a great wine for drinking after 10 years. Imported by Diageo Chateau & Estates.
title: Château Haut Batailley 2003  Pauillac

description: This Clerc-Milon, under the same winemaking team as Mouton Rothschild, is an attractive wine, not heavy, already quite soft. It seems to have been heavily extracted, in a New World style, with new wood aromas and flavors, losing something of Pauillac, but a winner in that it's immediately attractive. Imported by Diageo Chateau & Estates.
title: Château Clerc Milon 2003  Pauillac

description: On first whiff, it shows big fruit and vanilla, but it settles down on the palate to deliver cedary plum- and cassis-flavored fruit. Finishes long, with some dusty tannins. It's bulky and lacks a bit of grace, but it still makes for a satisfying mouthful of Bordeaux that should improve with time. Imported by Royal Wine Corporation.
title: Château Pontet-Canet 2002 Kosher  (Pauillac)

description: This wine has a distinctly herbal aroma and flavor. Sage, thyme and broccoli come to mind. The tannins are firm and frame secondary flavors redolent of coffee, plum and charry toast. Finishes with moderate length. Kosher.
title: Château Fonbadet 2000  Pauillac

description: The French call this wine harmonious, and it is balance that gives it its charm, its character and its intensity. It starts with black, dense fruits and only half way through do the tannins kick in. At the end, the whole is greater than the parts, with acidity the last lingering memory.
title: Château Clerc Milon 2000  Pauillac

description: The younger brother of Lafite, Duhart-Milon exhibits deliciously pure fruit. The wine is deceptively soft, because under the black jelly fruits, there are also dusty, dry, firm tannins. At the end, though, it is the vibrant fruit which lingers.
title: Château Duhart-Milon 2000  Pauillac

description: This is a new wine in this ever-expanding series. It reflects the structure and solid tannins of the appellation. It also brings out the juicy black-currant fruit of the vintage that will allow it to mature relatively quickly. Drink this attractive wine from 2019.
title: Kirkland Signature 2014  Pauillac

description: This blend of 65% Cabernet Sauvignon with Merlot comes from a small parcel of vineyards owned by the Borie family, which also has two Pauillac-classed growths. This wine is neat and finely formed with crisp fruit and attractive acidity. The tannins give support rather than domination. Drink from 2020.
title: Domaine de Saint-Guirons 2013  Pauillac

description: A small portion of Château Peyrabon lies in the Pauillac appellation and is vinified separately. This is a surprisingly light wine for its appellation, fresh with fruitiness rather than structured. It has attractive black-currant acidity and a core of smoky tannins. Drink from 2018.
title: Château la Fleur Peyrabon 2013  Pauillac

description: After the promise of the wine at its initial barrel tasting, this bottled wine is less exciting. Berry fruits are muted by the extracted tannins. It's likely the wine will develop quickly. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Lynch-Moussas 2013  Pauillac

description: This shows the lean character that comes from the vintage. But it's balanced with juicy black-fruit flavors and soft tannins that are now maturing. This is attractrive for a light, ready-to-drink wine.
title: Château Béhéré Courtin 2007  Pauillac

description: A wine that has freshness, some wood and a soft series of tannins, almost velvet. There is a stalky juiciness here, to complete a wine that offers the freshest acidity, with only hints of darker fruits.
title: Château Duhart-Milon 2007  Pauillac

description: A concentrated wine, relying on its generous black currant juice fruit rather than the more reticent tannins. The wine is dominated by Cabernet juiciness, a burst of fruit in the glass.
title: Château Clerc Milon 2007  Pauillac

description: The second wine of classed growth Château Duhart-Milon. With its mint and herbal aromas, its rich velvet texture flavored with black plums and damsons, this is already a sophisticated wine that will be ready to drink in a year.
title: Domaines Barons de Rothschild (Lafite) 2004 Moulin de Duhart  (Pauillac)

description: From the same stable as Haut-Brion, La Tour Haut-Brion reveals a fruity, almost frivolous character that makes it immediately charming. But there is no question that the soft, rich, black jelly fruits are the mask for a more concentrated, tannic structure. Give it 5-10 years.
title: Château La Tour Haut-Brion 2000  Pessac-Léognan

description: The wine shows the firmly tannic structure of the vintage. It is dense, packed with dark fruits and dry tannins that are slowly developing. That makes for a rich, black-fruited wine, concentrated and needing to age further. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Bardins 2010  Pessac-Léognan

description: While showing too much wood at the moment, this wine has potential. The red berries and black currants promise a fruity future with good tannins in support. Give the wine a few years and drink from 2019.
title: Château Larrivet Haut-Brion 2013  Pessac-Léognan

description: The enthusiastic use of wood for this wine gives a dark, spicy character that masks any fruit. Less new wood would have helped highlight the natural fruitiness of the wine. Leave it until 2020 and the fruit may fill out. Winemaker Stephan Carrier returned from Napa to take over winemaking after Irish businessman Lochlann Quinn bought the property in 2001.
title: Château de Fieuzal 2013  Pessac-Léognan

description: This is a concentrated wine, full of blackberry fruits with acidity and spice. The wood-aging character is balancing out well, giving structure without dominating the fruit. Drink from 2020. Grapes are vinified by variety and plot from the 60-acre vineyard of Cabernet Sauvignon (55%), Merlot (40%) and Petit Verdot (5%). The property was purchased by Jean-Christophe Mau in 2004.
title: Château Brown 2013  Pessac-Léognan

description: From one of the properties owned by André Lurton in Pessac-Léognan, this is a well-structured, wood-aged wine. Solid tannins and spice accompany coffee and bitter chocolate flavors. These are subsiding as the wine matures, leaving black currant fruits and a series of firm tannins that will allow the wine to age. Drink from 2017.
title: Château de Cruzeau 2012  Pessac-Léognan

description: Firm and tannic, this is a wine that offers good fruit along with its dark exterior. It has a smoky character, while the dark black fruit promises to give the wine a lift into the next 4-6 years.
title: Château Haut-Vigneau 2011  Pessac-Léognan

description: Produced at Château Haut-Bailly, this concentrated red show the attractive fruit of 2011. It's tannins are relatively gentle, a fine counter-point to the red berry and currant fruits. It's a wine for medium-term aging over the next 4-6 years.
title: Château le Pape 2011  Pessac-Léognan

description: Rounded and sweet wine, its tannins buried in the rich blackberry fruits. It is dominated by its fruity character, although there is a chunky texture that gives a firm mouthfeel. Ready to drink in a year.
title: Château le Pape 2008 L'Excellence  (Pessac-Léognan)

description: The Seze family has owned this estate since the 18th century, producing in 2009 a finely textured wine, one that has juicy black fruits and an elegant structure. It is a more structured take on the vintage, firm with dry tannins and acidity.
title: Château d'Eyran 2009  Pessac-Léognan

description: While it is not a powerful wine, it is elegant, balanced, with density of flavor and tannns, freshened by fruit acidity and red cherry and black currant fruits. Like many wines from 2007, this is for the medium term, and can even be drunk now.
title: Château Carbonnieux 2007  Pessac-Léognan

description: Owned by Sophie Lurton and her husband, Laurent Congombles, who also owns cru classé Château Bouscaut in the same appellation, this estate has produced a richly spicy wine, full of toasty flavors. The fruit is still developing behind this barrage of wood, but will come through as the wine matures. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Lamothe-Bouscaut 2015  Pessac-Léognan

description: With its high percentage of Cabernet Sauvignon (60%), this gives an initial serious structure, topped with rich, ripe black fruit flavors. The tannins are calmed by this richness, with spice, blueberries and blackberry juice much more dominant.
title: Château Brown 2006  Pessac-Léognan

description: Dense, sweet fruit, offering as much elegance as richness. It is poised, with pure, elegant fruit flavors. As it develops, the fruit is going to become more and more delicious, while the dusty tannins will soften to reveal great opulence.
title: Château La Grave à Pomerol 2000  Pomerol

description: The wine has bold fruit and ripe tannins. There is still a strong flavor from the wood aging although this should integrate. The fruit is the dominant character of this red-berry flavored wine. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Plince 2014  Pomerol

description: All about freshness, this wine has crisp red-currant flavors and bright acidity. The tannins are just a background to the juicy, fruity front. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Latour à Pomerol 2013  Pomerol

description: This is a big, bold and fruity wine, packed with ripe Merlot fruit. Juicy blackberry flavors have a fine shot of acidity and soft tannins. It's a warm wine that will age well over the medium-term. Drink from 2018.
title: Château la Patache 2012  Pomerol

description: Typical for Pomerol, this is a tiny property of seven acres. It is situated on the plateau close to Pomerol village center. It presents a bold display of Merlot, full of ripe tannins and jammy red berry fruits. It's dark, rich and maturing well, and will be ready to drink from 2017.
title: Château Lécuyer 2012  Pomerol

description: Pierhem is a small property of four acres. In 2010, it produced this ripe wine from richly structured Merlot and perfumed Cabernet Franc. This is an impressive, plush effort, layering its chocolate and toast components over the full-bodied blackberry-juice note.
title: Château Pierhem 2010  Pomerol

description: While the wine does have considerable tannins, it also has the ripe Merlot fruit to support it. Good acidity, black currant fruits, smoky wood, all the elements are there. It will always be firm, but should mature well.
title: Château Rocher-Bonregard 2008  Pomerol

description: Structured and firm, with tannins and some element of wood. There is sweetness here, flavors of licorice, blackberry juice and lively sweetness. The whole wine is dominated by delicious berry fruits.
title: Château Nenin 2007  Pomerol

description: The French often use the name Benjamin to indicate a youngest son, and this second wine from Château Beauregard exhibits all the youthful exuberance of a young wine. It doesn't have weight, but it does have balance and fresh acidity, given depth by wood.
title: Château Beauregard 2006 Le Benjamin de Beauregard  (Pomerol)

description: For Merlot from Pomerol, this wine has a surprising austerity to it. The tannins are initially dominant, with their leather character. But then, the layer of sweet juiciness does shine through, giving freshness and some vibrant flavors. It needs time to knit together though-give it at least four years.
title: Château l'Enclos 2006  Pomerol

description: For a solid mouthful of Merlot at a great price, there's no need to look further. Spicy blackberry and toast aromas add vanilla on the palate, before finishing with soft, ripe tannins and leathery notes. Drink now-2008. Editors' Choice.
title: Malesan 1999 Chateau Prieure Malesan  (Premieres Cotes de Blaye)

description: Ripe, smooth, rich fruits, juicy strawberry flavor and fresh acidity. The texture is solid and dense, with an obvious potential for aging.
title: Château La Rame 2006 La Charmille  (Premieres Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: Firmly structured, showing dense tannins over the black currant fruits and fresh acidity, this is an attractively balanced wine, packed with ripe fruit from the great 2005 vintage, but keeping its freshness and elegance.
title: Château Lagarosse 2005  Premieres Cotes de Bordeaux

description: Owned by the Despagne family, who make some of the best whites from the Entre-deux-Mers, Mont-Pérat is one of the family's red wine estates. This is dominated by Merlot, giving great juicy fruit flavors, underpinned by some wood, and a velvet, ripe texture.
title: Château Mont-Pérat 2004  Premieres Cotes de Bordeaux

description: This dense wine is packed with firm tannins and concentrated fruit. A blend of ripe Merlot and perfumed Cabernet Franc, it has weight, with layers of black-plum skin flavors and dark tannins. With its firm dry core, it is still young. Drink from 2021.
title: Château des Laurets 2015  Puisseguin Saint-Émilion

description: The blend of 90% Merlot and 10% Cabernet Franc gives this wine a rich character. It does have a firm edge of tannins still producing a dry character that needs to soften. The juicy black currants are developing well and should balance the tannins in a year or two. Drink this solid wine from 2018.
title: Château Roc de Boissac 2012  Puisseguin Saint-Émilion

description: Richly endowed with ripe Merlot, this spicy, smoky, full-bodied wine is already developing. It is smooth, concentrated and deliciously juicy. Spice and firm tannins are well in the background, leaving room for acidity and black fruits. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Haut-Bernat 2011  Puisseguin Saint-Émilion

description: Aged in vats without any wood aging, this wine is exuberantly fruity. Ripe with Merlot, its blackberry flavors and generous fruit tannins are open. Acidity and the crisp texture at the end contrast with the full-bodied core of the wine. Drink this powerful, yet still crisp, wine from 2021
title: Château la Croix Teynac 2015  Puisseguin Saint-Émilion

description: This still-young blackberry-rich wine is bursting with fruit. Its structure is restrained, with a background of tannins that support the juicy fruitiness. Produced from organic grapes, it will need to age further, so drink from 2019.
title: Château Puisseguin la Rigodrie 2015  Puisseguin Saint-Émilion

description: The spicy tannins in this wine are still firm and will probably not soften further. A dry core balanced by the rich blackberry fruit and acidity gives the wine freshness and a ripe aftertaste. Drink now.
title: Château Pas de l'Ane 2011  Saint-Émilion

description: This smoky wine has generous fruit and well-balanced tannins. It is still young, with a core of dryness. Black fruits show the potential of this ripe wine. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Jupille Carillon 2015 Cuvée Prestige  (Saint-Émilion)

description: From vines situated just west of the small city of Saint-Émilion, this estate has produced a fruity wine. Its fruity character is typical of the vintage, berry flavors and acidity cushioning the tannins and wood accents. It's a juicy wine to drink now.
designation: Le Différent de Château de Ferrand
title: Château de Ferrand 2014 Le Différent de Château de Ferrand  (Saint-Émilion)

description: Powerful and dense, this wine has an extracted character, with licorice and dark chocolate flavors. It is young and hopefully the bitterness will go, because the fruit and generous tannins are looking good. Wait until 2022.
title: Château Clos Junet 2016  Saint-Émilion

description: From an estate situated close to the vineyards of Pomerol, the 82% Merlot in this blend gives a sumptuous wine that will be ripe and full when it matures. The obtrusive wood flavors need to calm down first, so wait to drink the wine until 2022.
title: Château Haut-Cadet 2015  Saint-Émilion

description: This chateau shows continual improvement, and 2000 is a triumph. The wine is in a modern style, although at this stage its tannins are still firm and dry. Red fruit flavors and blackcurrants promise huge drinking pleasure to come.
title: Château Larmande 2000  Saint-Émilion

description: From a Grand Cru estate, this second wine shows the same rich fruit and generous structure as the winery's first wine. It's just softer with an approachable character and generous black fruits that will enable it to mature relatively quickly. Drink from 2020.
title: Château de Pressac 2014 Les Terrasses de Pressac  (Saint-Émilion)

description: The Figeac sector of Saint-Emilion has many estates that split off in the 19th century from a grand Château Figeac estate. This Moreaud family wine is smooth, with the fruitiness typical of the vintage and with a gentle layer of tannins to hold it all together. It will age quickly and should be ready to drink from 2019.
title: Château Cormeil-Figeac 2014 Cuvée Haut-Cormeil  (Saint-Émilion)

description: The wine is tight with tannins and a dense texture. It has plenty of fruit underneath to allow this blend of Cabernet Franc and Merlot to balance out. Perfumed and with fine acidity, the wine should be ready from 2019.
title: Château la Clide 2011 Moulin du Château la Clide  (Saint-Émilion)

description: The tannins of this firm wine are softening well to give richness as well as structure. With juicy black currants, it is going to be a solid, dense wine. This is the second wine of the family-owned Grand Pontent which is managed by a member of the Bécot family of classed growth Beauséjour-Bécot. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Grand Pontet 2011 Dauphin de Grand Pontet  (Saint-Émilion)

description: The wine shows the firm tannins of the vintage. They give a dry core that will probably remain. However, there is also a fine layer of fresh black-currant fruit that gives a fine lift to the wine at the end. It will be ready soon, drink from 2017.
title: Château de Lescours 2011  Saint-Émilion

description: With 90% Merlot, this is a full supple wine from the eastern end of Saint-Emilion. There are tannins that support the perfumed blackberry fruit and the balanced acidity. The wine is ready to drink now, although it will be better from 2017.
title: Château Béard la Chapelle 2012  Saint-Émilion

description: The 30-year-old vines of this estate surround a 16th-century castle. The wine is ripe although with intense acidity at the end. Wood aging has added spice and has smoothed out the bright acidity and red-berry fruits. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Cruzeau 2014  Saint-Émilion

description: A vineyard on the river plain of Saint-Émilion, Haut-Pezat has produced a wine whose full black fruits handle strong wood-aging flavors with ease. The result is a ripe wine packed with blackberry flavors and acidity that is filled out with the wood spice. The wine should age well, drink from 2020.
title: Château Haut-Pezat 2014  Saint-Émilion

description: This ripe, juicy and fruity wine has plenty of tannins, although they have easily integrated into the black fruits and fresh acidity. The wine is already surprisingly balanced, so although it will improve with age, it can be enjoyed now.
title: Château Laroque 2013  Saint-Émilion

description: Already balanced, this is a rich wine, packed with jammy fruit and tannins. The concentration contrasts with the intense, fresh acidity. Good depth of flavor comes with a dense texture and a final shot of pure acidity. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Laforge 2013  Saint-Émilion

description: While this wine certainly has a firmly tannic character, it is the fruit that shines. Black currants and perfumed spicy berry fruits are right up there along with the juicy acidity. This is a blend of 70% Merlot, 20% Cabernet Sauvignon and 10% Cabernet Franc. It is well balanced although it needs to age. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Fleur du Roc 2012  Saint-Émilion

description: Heavily Merlot-weighted, this offers rich while still-fresh fruit. With dense tannins and an impressive blend of acidity and dark structure, it shows the fruitiness of the vintage while keeping an ability to age. Drink now, but better to wait until 2017.
title: Cheval Quancard 2012 1844  (Saint-Émilion)

description: Firm and solidly structured, this is a dense wine. It has plenty of tannins and a touch of bitter chocolate, but they are supported by the ripe fruit and fresh black currant flavors. It's a wine for aging, drink from 2017.
title: Château Lagrave 2012 Le Second  (Saint-Émilion)

description: This generous and full-bodied wine is full of juicy red berry fruits, ripe tannins and just enough structure to support its opulent character. Wood aging gives a fine-grained texture that will allow it to age. Drink from 2016.
title: Château la Chapelle aux Moines 2010  Saint-Émilion

description: This is a perfumed, aromatic wine with great acidity and fresh black fruits. The wine is already softening with a good fruity character, fresh and bright at the end.
title: Château Teyssier 2011  Saint-Émilion

description: While it does have a tannic structure, this wine is characterized by its ripe fruits, rich texture and softness. Strong plum jelly and spice are nicely combined to give an in-the-mouth fruitiness that's freshened by the final acidity. Drink this wine from 2017.
title: Clos Junet 2010  Saint-Émilion

description: Rich, concentrated wine, with generous fruits and soft tannins. It has super-ripe black plums, a touch of chocolate and spice from wood aging. Powerful, juicy, fruity, likely to age well over the medium-term, over the next 3-4 years.
title: Clos Larcis 2009  Saint-Émilion

description: There is great fruit on this ripe, full-bodied wine. The fruit is already well integrated with the tannins, giving a juicy feel and a black currant fragrance. Rich, open and soft, finishing with an elegant structure.
title: Château Teyssier 2010  Saint-Émilion

description: Dominated by Merlot, this is a fruity and rich wine, rounded, ripe and spicy. It has density and weight, layered with dusty rich tannins. With its spice, blackberry acidity and chunky feel, it is already drinkable, but will age over several years.
title: Château Laforge 2009  Saint-Émilion

description: Big, dense wine, with dusty tannins and ripe red plum fruits. The wine is concentrated, fruity while also structured. It is already balanced, the acidity giving freshness, the texture showing the delicious ripe character of the vintage.
title: Château Tour de Lagarde 2009  Saint-Émilion

description: A wine from a Château that is still finding its form . It is soft, open, with attractive juicy red fruits and black currants, ready to drink soon.
title: Château Soutard 2009  Saint-Émilion

description: Soft, dusty tannins balance a wine that is full of the ripest fruit. It has power, but gentle power, with rounded corners and a texture that is dense, never hard. The fruits are ripe plums, perhaps lacking final freshness.
title: Château de Ferrand 2005  Saint-Émilion

description: Situated on the plateau of Saint-Emilion, just east of the city, Château le Prieuré has produced a finely structured 2007, not big, but well balanced. Touches of cocoa and cinnamon spice cap the solid fruit and dry tannins. Age for 3-4 years.
title: Château le Prieuré 2007 Grand Cru Classé  (Saint-Émilion)

description: With its dry, tight texture, this is an austere wine. The fruit is full of piercing black currant acidity, structured with firm tannins. Smoky wood does give an extra dimension, but the wine needs several months more in bottle.
title: Château Bellerose Figeac 2007 Cuvée Tradition  (Saint-Émilion)

description: Wood dominates this wine, the wine itself relatively light, but finely composed. There are spicy tannins with intense acidity, crisp black currants, bursting through the overlay of wood.
title: Château Troplong Mondot 2007  Saint-Émilion

description: A ripe, big solid wine, almost chunky in character, smooth and velvet in texture, without much in the way of tannins. Its attractive chocolate flavors give it ripeness and make it ready to drink.
title: Château Magdelaine 2007  Saint-Émilion

description: There is a good core of tannin here, the fruit sweet plums and ripe tannins, relatively soft and easy. Only that kernel of tannin offers some aging possibility.
title: Clos Fourtet 2007  Saint-Émilion

description: Firm and dry with serious wood aging, this wine's fruit is still waiting to develop. Luckily it has the richness to become a full, spicy wine. Hints of the blackberry fruits are there, so wait until 2022 for this bold wine to develop.
title: Château Jupille Carillon 2015 Cuvée Prestige  (Saint-Émilion)

description: This generous and fruity wine, the equivalent of a third wine from this property, is richly structured and has firm tannins. The structure goes along with the full black-fruit flavors and acidity to give a wine that has good potential. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Fleur Cardinale 2016 Le Saint-Émilion de Fleur Cardinale  (Saint-Émilion)

description: Although the fruit says this wine is mature, the structure makes it firm and dry. Typical of this always-tough vintage, the wine is packed with firm tannins and concentration. Drink now.
title: Château Destieux 2011  Saint-Émilion

description: The second wine of Château Corbin, this is ripe and rounded. It's a juicy Merlot, with generous tannins and smooth blackberry fruit. It has a dense texture as well as a dry core that will allow the wine to age. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Corbin 2015 Divin de Corbin  (Saint-Émilion)

description: Profiting from the ripeness of the 2015 vintage, this 65% Merlot wine is rich and soft. The balance of Cabernet Franc in the blend lends spice, perfume and a fine tannic structure. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Belle Assise Coureau 2015  Saint-Émilion

description: Now blossoming, this wine from a generally fruity vintage is delicious to drink. Poised and stylish, it shows integrated black fruit and wood, feeling balanced and almost ready. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Tour Grand Faurie 2012  Saint-Émilion

description: This second wine from the estate offers spice and mushroom aromas that indicate it's now mature. Ripe and smooth, with attractive secondary flavors, it's spicy, meaty and ready to drink.
title: Château Valade 2012 L'Etendard de Château Valade  (Saint-Émilion)

description: This dense wine is now beginning to mature. It has the bold black fruit of the vintage, which is overlaid by dark chocolate notes and some bitterness. Still firm, it will probably need to age. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Pailhas 2012  Saint-Émilion

description: Fine tannins, dusty and sweet, play a major part in the success of this wine. It's fruit, initially subdued by the tannins, then bursts through with cherry jelly, dark plums and an edge of licorice. It's certainly rich, but it all hangs together well.
title: Château Candale 2005 Roc de Candale  (Saint-Émilion)

description: Dominated by new wood, this wine has not yet found its true character. It will likely become rich and juicy, with black plum and spice flavors coming forward in 2-3 years. For the moment, it is all about firmness and dryness.
title: Château Grand Destieu 2006  Saint-Émilion

description: This particular estate is small but has produced some good, solidly juicy ripe wine, with big black fruit and mocha flavors.
title: Château Cormeil-Figeac 2003  Saint-Émilion

description: Starts off with vanilla and black cherry scents, with just a sprinkling of dried herbs. This blend of 60% Merlot and 40% Cabernet Franc is creamy and supple through the mocha-tinged midpalate, then finishes crisper than expected, with some dusty tannins. Drink 2008-2015. Imported by Acadia Imports.
title: Château Vignot 2003  Saint-Émilion

description: Meyney is often the most gentle of the great estates of Saint-Estéphe, and in 2003 this character is most obvious. The wine is full of vitality and ripeness, soft tannins showing the property more than the hot year. The fruit dominates right through the wine, with dryness only appearing in the aftertaste.
title: Château Meyney 2003  Saint-Estéphe

description: A powerful, spicy wine that is dominated by wood and toast. The fruit is black but relatively lightweight, and is suffering at this stage from the strong wood flavors.
title: Château Phélan-Ségur 2002  Saint-Estéphe

description: Typical of  Saint-Estéphe, this wine is totally closed up. It is more tannins than fruit at this stage of its development. But it is obvious that there is fruit there, and that it will develop. But for now, it's a case of watch this space.
title: Château Meyney 2000  Saint-Estéphe

description: With its fine, ripe tannins and immediately attractive acidity, this is a wine which looks set to develop relatively fast but with style.
title: Château les Ormes de Pez 2000  Saint-Estéphe

description: The wine is almost mature. It has a minty edge with some firm tannins and plenty of balanced fruit and acidity. It benefits from the propitious conditions in this appellation during the difficult 2013 vintage and shows ripe fruit and a generous berry aftertaste. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Coussieu-Coutelin 2013  Saint-Estéphe

description: What is so good about this wine is its balance. The producer has accentuated the fruit of the vintage, leaving aside any big tannic structure. The result is a black-currant wine that is juicy, fresh and developing well. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Le Boscq 2013  Saint-Estéphe

description: Still firm, this has dark chocolate and polished wood flavors, as well as dark plums and berries. With the tight acidity, it's a wine for aging, dark and concentrated for the future. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Bel-Air Ortet 2011  Saint-Estéphe

description: Very dry at the start, this opens up well to give a rich and fruity wine. The tannins are still powerful and show that the wine needs to age. With licorice and smoky flavors, the wood element is still very present. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Ségur de Cabanac 2011  Saint-Estéphe

description: A mint- and spice-flavored wine, this has concentrated tannins that structure the black plum and berry fruits. The flavors are rich, and the dense texture promises several years of aging.
title: Château la Haye 2010  Saint-Estéphe

description: At this stage, a wine that is dominated by wood. The weight and the ripe fruit are there as well to suggest potential dark fruits, black plums, damsons and a juicy character. The rich fruit should begin to show well in a year, but the wine needs aging 3-4 years.
title: Château Cossieu-Coutelin 2009  Saint-Estéphe

description: A ripe wine, the wood a band of flavor through the sweet tannins and attractive fresh fruits. It has the lightness of the year, leaving the flavors coming from the bright fruits.
title: Château Cos Labory 2007  Saint-Estéphe

description: A lusciously rich wine whose opulence is tempered by some firm, dry tannins as well as crisp acidity. The superripe plum and blackberry fruits are open, generous and demanding to be drunk in the next 2-3 years.
title: Château Haut-Beauséjour 2004  Saint-Estéphe

description: From an estate that claims to date back to Roman times and has been revived by the current owners, this attractive wine features dusty tannins and ripe, juicy blackberry-flavored Merlot. A touch of perfume and plenty of acidity at the end keep it fresh. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Saint-André Corbin 2013  Saint-Georges-Saint-Émilion

description: A solid wine, well structured, with soft but supple tannins that frame a core of blackberry, cassis, toast, coffee, anise and herb notes. The finish has a hint of sage and thyme, ending with moderate length. Good Bordeaux from a good year. Kosher
title: Château Léoville Poyferré 2000  Saint-Julien

description: This is an excellent wine, full of ripe fruit and blackcurrant flavors, showing style and elegance in its balancing tannins. It is typical of this property in already showing signs of developing fast. Give it five years.
title: Château Lalande-Borie 2000  Saint-Julien

description: This wine is finely structured with the red berry and black plum fruit flavors leading to a central core of tannins. There is good juiciness as well, the whole ensemble promising good medium-term aging. The second wine of Château du Glana.
title: Château du Glana 2008 Terre du Lion  (Saint-Julien)

description: Ripe, smooth chocolate flavors with a soft structure and plenty or ripe fruit. There is a streak of acidity, the tannins are dusty, but the wine is generally soft in character.
title: Château Lalande-Borie 2007  Saint-Julien
